Covid-19 Pandemic

General Websites

Websites by Public Authorities and International Organisations

The websites in this section were used or specifically created by governments or international organisations to track the progress of the pandemic, inform the general public or both.

  • World Health Organization (WHO):
    • Coronavirus disease (COVID-19) Pandemic;
    • Coronavirus disease (COVID-19) outbreak, WHO/Europe;
    • Flambée de maladie à coronavirus 2019 (COVID-19), Organisation mondiale de la santé (in French);
    • Naming the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) and the virus that causes it;
    • Coronavirus disease (COVID-2019) situation reports day-by-day reports since 21.01.2020.
  • Coronavirus: arbeitsrechtliche Informationen, Bundesministeriums für Arbeit und Soziales (BMAS).
  • Coronavirus COVID-19 (Belgium).
  • Coronavirus (COVID-19) - NHS (UK).
  • Coronavirus (COVID-19), Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (USA).
  • Coronavirus (COVID-19), National Institutes of Health (USA).
  • Zusammen gegen Corona (Bundesministerium für Gesundheit) (Germany).
  • COVID-19 (Coronavirus), gov.ie (Ireland).

Websites by Other Organisations

This section lists websites by research institutions, non-profit organisations, and private companies.

  • Coronavirus COVID-19 Global Cases by the Center for Systems Science and Engineering (CSSE) at Johns Hopkins University (JHU).
  • Genomic epidemiology of novel coronavirus - Global subsampling, Nextstrain.
  • COVID-19, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).
  • COVID-19 Resource Centre, The Lancet.
  • The COVID Tracking Project: this project has a data API and a GitHub repository.
  • Europe: the latest coronavirus counts, charts and maps, Reuters (accessed on 07.06.2021).
  • Coronavirus Disease (COVID-19) – Statistics and Research, Our World In Data.
  • COVID-19, Good Judgment (Superforecaster® Analytics).
  • COVID-19 (Coronavirus SARS-CoV-2) & COVID-19 (Coronavirus SARS-CoV-2) & Empfehlungen des RKI zu Hygienemaßnahmen im Rahmen der Behandlung und Pflege von Patienten mit einer Infektion durch SARS-CoV-2, Robert Koch Institut.
  • Coronavirus: Gesammelte Informationen, Apotheken Umschau.
  • FAQ-Liste zu SARS-CoV-2, Charité – Universitätsmedizin Berlin.
  • Novel coronavirus (COVID-19) cases by country worldwide 2020, Statista.
    These data can be downloaded in several formats: PDF, Excel, PNG and others. Access to some of these data requires an account.
  • Coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic, Inclusion Europe. This website also provides easy-to-read information about the COVID-19 pandemic.
  • Covid Data Transparency Index (CDTI), TotalAnalysis.
  • Coronavirus (COVID-19) (Patient.info, UK).
  • Lex Corona – Übersicht über Rechtsakte der deutschen Bundesländer: website by a lawfirm in Mainz, Germany, that tracks all decrees and laws enacted in Germany in response to the Corona epidemic.
  • Wo tritt Coronavirus auf? Echtzeit-Karte zeigt die Verbreitung der Krankheit, Focus.
  • COVID-19 reports, Imperial College London.
  • Informationen zum Coronavirus, Bundesvereinigung Deutscher Apothekerverbände (ABDA).
    This page contains links to downloads (both for patients and pharmacists) and articles on the ABDA website.
  • COVID-19 (Coronavirus) Data Hub , Tableau.
  • Kekulés Corona-Kompass, MDR.DE: daily podcasts by the virologist Alexander Kekulé.
  • Corona-Plots und Interpretationshilfen, garantiert unaufgeregt., D. Kriesel.
  • Coronavirus COVID-19 Scientific Research and Resources, Pfizer.
  • Corona-Akutdiagnostik, CeGaT, 2020.
  • Corona Locator Nederland.
  • Tijdlijn corona Nederland.
  • BARDA’s Rapidly Expanding COVID-19 Medical Countermeasure Portfolio, Medical Countermeasures (U.S. Department of Health & Human Services) (updated regularly).
  • How Severe Is Your State's Coronavirus Outbreak?, NPR.
  • Möglichkeiten und Grenzen der eigenverantwortlichen Wiederverwendung von FFP2-Masken für den Privatgebrauch, FH Münster.
    This is a guide about masks that can be consulted as a webpage and downloaded as a PDF document.
  • Corona-Impfungen in Deutschland: So viele Menschen wurden bisher gegen Covid-19 geimpft, ZEIT ONLINE (accessed on 30.03.2021).
  • Explore SARS-CoV-2 evolution, Nextstrain (accessed on 23.06.2021).
    See also the Nextstrain GitHub repository.

Risk Calculators and Exposure Modelers

  • Aerosole: So senken Sie Ihr Coronavirus-Risiko in Innenräumen, ZEIT ONLINE, November 2020.
    Calculator that helps you estimate the risk of getting infected in a room with one infected person, based on the room's size, the number of persons in the room and the duration of your stay in that room.
  • COVID-19 DataViewer, VSP / Technische Universität Berlin, 11.11.2020.
  • COVID 19 Aerosol Transmission Risk Calculator, Max-Planck-Institut für Chemie, Max-Planck-Gesellschaft.
    This calculator is based on the following publication: Jos Lelieveld, Frank Helleis, Stephan Borrmann, Yafang Cheng, Frank Drewnick, Gerald Haug, Thomas Klimach, Jean Sciare, Hang Su, Ulrich Pöschl: Algorithm to estimate Covid-19 infections risks by aerosol transmission in indoor environments.
  • COVID-19 Personal Risk Calculator, CovidOdds.com.
    This tool is based on the data produced by the Centre for Global Infectious Disease Analysis at the Imperial College London led by Prof. Neil Ferguson.
  • COVID exposure modeler / Estimation of COVID-19 infection risk from airborne transmission during classroom teaching by Prasad Kasibhatla, Jose Jimenez, John Fay, Elizabeth Albright and William Pan (Duke University). For the tool's source code, see Covid exposure modeling (GitHub).
  • COVID-19 Event Risk Assessment Planning Tool: a collaborative project led by Prof. Joshua Weitz and Prof. Clio Andris at the Georgia Institute of Technology, along with researchers at the Applied Bioinformatics Laboratory and Stanford University, and powered by RStudio. It is based on the paper Real-time, interactive website for US-county-level COVID-19 event risk assessment (Nature Human Behaviour, 09 November 2020).

Wikipedia

Wikipedia has a set of web pages covering the Covid-19 pandemic, for example:

  • Portal:Coronavirus disease 2019.
  • 2019–20 coronavirus pandemic
  • 2019–20 coronavirus pandemic by country and territory, with many pages covering individual continents and countries, for example, 2019–20 coronavirus pandemic in mainland China, 2020 coronavirus pandemic in South Korea, 2020 coronavirus pandemic in Europe, 2020 coronavirus pandemic in Italy, 2020 coronavirus pandemic in Spain and 2020 coronavirus pandemic in the United States.
  • Timeline of the 2019–20 coronavirus pandemic: this page lists relevant pages that provide a timeline per month.
  • COVID-19 vaccine.
  • Timeline of the 2019–20 coronavirus pandemic in November 2019 – January 2020 (Wikipedia).
    Quotes:
    • 30 December: After receiving the test result, multiple doctors in Wuhan shared the information via internet, including Dr. Li Wenliang, an ophthalmologist at Wuhan Central Hospital, who posted a warning to alumni from his medical school class via a WeChat online forum that a cluster of seven patients treating within the ophthalmology department had been unsuccessfully treated for symptoms of viral pneumonia and diagnosed with SARS. (…) The Chinese National Health Commission announced later that evening that 8 doctors engaging in this WeChat forum had been arrested by Wuhan Police and charged with "illegal acts of fabricating, spreading rumors and disrupting social order."
    • 3 January: On 3 January 2020, Dr. Li Wenliang, the Wuhan ophthalmologist who had been arrested for spreading false "rumors" on WeChat, was summoned to the Wuhan Public Security Bureau where he was told to sign an official confession and admonition letter promising to cease spreading false "rumors" regarding the coronavirus. In the letter, he was accused of "making false comments" that had "severely disturbed the social order". The letter stated, "We solemnly warn you: If you keep being stubborn, with such impertinence, and continue this illegal activity, you will be brought to justice—is that understood?" Dr. Li signed the confession writing: "Yes, I understand."
    • 21 January: After 300 confirmed diagnoses and 6 deaths, Chinese state media warned lower-level officials not to cover up the spread of a new coronavirus. (…) [The political body responsible for law and order] ater vastly under-reported the number of people that had been infected, downplayed the risks and failed to provide timely information that experts say could have saved lives.
    • 24 January: By the end of the day, the entire Hubei province had gone under a city-by-city quarantine, apart from Xiangyang and Shennongjia Forestry District.
    • 27 January: three-hour presentation by Dr. Gabriel Leung published on YouTube: He stated that draconian measures were needed to slow the progress of the virus but that these measures would have no effect in stopping the coronavirus pandemic. He projected that the number of infections would continue exponentially peaking out in late April or May 2020. This presentation was followed by the publication of an article in The Lancet.
    • 28 January: China's Supreme People's Court ruled that whistleblower, Li Wenliang, had not committed the crime of spreading "rumors" when on 30 December 2019 he posted to a WeChat forum for medical school alumni that seven patients under his care appeared to have contracted SARS. Xiangyang became quarantined starting 00:00;[245] the entire Hubei province thus became quarantined save for Shennongjia Forestry District.

Other resources:

  • Face Masks (on this site).
  • Private Kit: Safe Paths- Can we slow the spread without giving up individual privacy? MIT (no date).
  • Coronavirus and philosophers, European Journal of Psychoanalysis (no date; March 2020).
  • How Much Toilet Paper?! - The Coronavirus Toilet Paper Calculator.

Day-by-Day Articles and Updates

January 2020

  • Mystery illness outbreak in Wuhan, China (South China Morning Post on YouTube, 2 minutes, 04.01.2020).
  • Bamford, Connor: Mystery China pneumonia outbreak likely caused by new human coronavirus, The Conversaton, 13.01.2020 (Creative Commons).
  • Public Health Screening to Begin at 3 U.S. Airports for 2019 Novel Coronavirus (“2019-nCoV”), Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), 17.01.2020.
  • Celestial, Julie: Major Chinese city goes into lockdown as new virus death toll rises to at least 17 - Wuhan, Hubei, The Watchers, 23.01.2020.
  • Feng, Emily; Cheng, Amy; Kennedy, Merrit: Chinese Authorities Begin Quarantine Of Wuhan City As Coronavirus Cases Multiply, NPR, 23.01.2020.
  • Williams, Shawna: Where Coronaviruses Come From, The Scientist Magazine, 24.01.2020.
    This is an interview with infectious disease researcher Peter Daszak, president of the nonprofit EcoHealth Alliance.
  • Higgins, Tucker: Trump thanks China’s Xi Jinping for handling of coronavirus, CNBC, 24.01.2020.
  • Linde, Pablo: Los dos casos sospechosos por el virus de Wuhan en España dan negativo, EL PAÍS, 25.01.2020.
  • Palmer, James: Don’t Blame Bat Soup for the Coronavirus, Foreign Policy, 27.01.2020.
    A video that went viral showed a Chinese woman biting into a bat that she held up using chopsticks. However, the video wasn't even from China.
  • Madrigal, Alexis C.: How to Misinform Yourself About the Coronavirus, The Atlantic, 28.01.2020.
    This article is about epidemiologist Eric Feigl-Ding's Twtter thread from 20 January 2020.
  • Mittler, Dietrich: Erster Coronavirus-Fall in Deutschland bestätigt, Süddeutsche Zeitung, 28.01.2020.
    A speaker of the Bavarian ministry of health said that the first case of SARS-Cov-2 had been detected in an employee of the company Webasto. Earlier the same week that a Chinese employee, who had been in Munich from 19 till 22 January, had bee diagnosed with SARS-Cov-2 on 26 January, after her return to China.
  • The Wuhan coronavirus has nothing to do with 5G, Full Fact, 29.01.2020.
  • Pawlowski, A.: Coronavirus outbreak: Can face masks protect you? Stores sell out of masks, Today, 29.01.2020.
  • Kennedy, Merrit: WHO Declares Coronavirus Outbreak A Global Health Emergency, NPR, 30.01.2020.
  • Chappell, Bill: Coronavirus Has Now Spread To All Regions Of Mainland China, NPR, 30.01.2020.
  • Chappell, Bill: 1st Person-To-Person Spread Of Coronavirus Has Occurred In U.S., CDC Says, NPR, 30.01.2020.
  • Coronavirus Wuhan diary: Living alone in a city gone quiet, BBC News, 30.01.2020.
  • Neale, Spencer: 'Draconian measures': China allegedly cremating coronavirus victims in secret, Washington Examiner, 30.01.2020.
    Quote: As the official death toll in China eclipsed 170 on Thursday, Hong Kong–based digital outlet Initium Media published an article interviewing doctors who said they were sending dead victims of the virus to be cremated.
    The article also cites William Yang's tweet from 29.01.2020: Just to add a bit more to what was mentioned in the show but I wasn’t able to elaborate on - #China’s state media has been reporting about building new hospitals dedicated to treating #Wuhanvirus patients in multiple provinces and cities, which I think reflect the ... ... seriousness of the spread in #China, but also the lack of facilities that can handle the rising number of patients.
  • Chen, Fei: Coronavirus: why China’s strategy to contain the virus might work, The Conversation, 30.01.2020 (Creative Commons).
  • Prof. Dr. Christian Drosten: Coronavirus-Experte im Interview vom 30.01.2020 | Talk aus Berlin (rbb on YouTube, 30 minutes, 30.01.2020.
    At the time of this interview, Christian Drosten did not expect a pandemic. After explaining that roughly 2% of people infected with Covid-19 in Wuhan had died, he said: Das ist dann schon eine hohe Zahl, Wenn man sich das vorstellt als eine Erkrankung, die sich mit dieser Eigenschaft, mit dieser Krankmachenden Wirkung dann weltweit verbreiten würde. Also eine Pandemie, eine Seuchenfallsterblichkeit. Und das erwarte ich überhaupt nicht, da muss ich jetzt wirklich einfach, auch in diesem Gespräch, wieder vorwegschicken: So wird is nicht sein, so dramatisch wie ich jetzt gleich die Vergleichszahlen nennen werde. (…)
  • Dey, Kunal: Wuhan coronavirus: China is secretly cremating bodies and lying in the official figures, say shocking reports, MEAWW, 31.01.2020.
    Quote: As the official death toll from coronavirus in China skyrocketed to 170 -- with a staggering 7,711 cases reported on Thursday -- Hong Kong-based outlet Initium Media published an article interviewing doctors who claimed they were sending dead victims of the virus to be cremated, the Washington Examiner reports.
  • Josephs, Leslie; Breuninger, Kevin: Trump imposes travel restrictions, mandatory quarantines over coronavirus outbreak, CNBC, 31.01.2020.
    Quote: The Trump administration on Friday declared the coronavirus a public health emergency in the United States, and announced that certain foreign nationals deemed to pose a risk of transmitting the disease will temporarily be denied entry to the U.S. Some returning American citizens potentially at risk will be quarantined.

February 2020

  • Aguilera, Jasmine: Xenophobia 'Is A Pre-Existing Condition.' How Harmful Stereotypes and Racism are Spreading Around the Coronavirus, Time, 01.02.2020, updated 03.02.2020.
  • Coronavirus-Fall in München, Süddeutsche Zeitung, 02.02.2020.
    Another Webasto employee was diagnosed with SARS-Cov-2, increasing the total number of cases in Bavaria to 8.
  • Hollingsworth, Julia: The memory of SARS looms over the Wuhan virus. Here's how the outbreaks compare, CNN, 02.02.2020.
  • Coronavirus will be here for some months, says health secretary, BBC News, 03.02.2020.
  • Gifford-Jones, W.: DR. W. GIFFORD-JONES: People are dying needlessly of coronavirus, Bakersfield.com, 03.02.2020.
    Quote: Dr. Andrew W. Saul, an international expert on vitamin therapy, says, “The coronavirus can be dramatically slowed or stopped completely with the immediate widespread use of high doses of vitamin C. Bowel tolerance levels of C taken in divided doses throughout the day, is a clinically proven antiviral, without equal.”
  • Allemandou, Ségolène: Coronavirus : le quotidien du Dr Klein, médecin des expatriés français de Wuhan, France 24, 04.02.2020.
  • Vulnerable Pacific islands take hard line on coronavirus, The Straits Times, 04.02.2020.
  • Hegarty, Stephanie: The Chinese doctor who tried to warn others about coronavirus, BBC News, 06.02.2020.
  • Pompeo, Michael R.: The United States Announces Assistance To Combat the Novel Coronavirus, United States Department of State, 07.02.2020.
    Quote: This week the State Department has facilitated the transportation of nearly 17.8 tons of donated medical supplies to the Chinese people, including masks, gowns, gauze, respirators, and other vital materials. These donations are a testament to the generosity of the American people.
    (Note that Donald Trump later blamed previous governments (i.e. Barack Obama) for the lack of equipment instead of his own government's failure to replenish the stock. See Trump SENT Ventilators & Masks to China, Blames OBAMA for Shortage (David Pakman Show on YouTube, 6 minutes, 04.04.2020).)
  • Li Wenliang: Coronavirus kills Chinese whistleblower doctor, BBC News, 07.02.2020.
  • Neuman, Scott; Feng, Emily; Huo, Jingnan: China To Investigate After Whistleblower Doctor Dies From Coronavirus, NPR, 07.02.2020.
    Quote: Li, 34, had first sought to warn his college classmates in the medical profession of the disease in late December. Using the popular Chinese social media platform WeChat, Li wrote that he had become aware of several cases similar to severe acute respiratory syndrome, or SARS, another coronavirus that killed nearly 800 people in a 2002-2003 outbreak that Beijing initially tried to cover up.
  • Chinese whistle-blower doctor who died fighting coronavirus only wanted people to 'know the truth', The Straits Times, 07.02.2020.
  • Zhou, Cissy: Coronavirus: Whistle-blower Dr Li Wenliang confirmed dead of the disease at 34, after hours of chaotic messaging from hospital, South China Morning Post, 07.02.2020.
    Quote: Li Wenliang – one of the first doctors who tried to alert the public about the coronavirus outbreak, only to be reprimanded by local police – has died, Wuhan Central Hospital confirmed early Friday morning, hours after it initially denied reports of his death.
  • Alexander, Lamar; Burr, Richard: Sen. Alexander & Sen. Burr: Coronavirus prevention steps the U.S. government is taking to protect you, Fox News, 07.02.2020.
  • Wetsman, Nicole: Handshake bans to stop the coronavirus might be overkill in most places, The Verge, 07.02.2020.
    Handshake bans are not a new idea. The risk of a handshake, though, is related to hand hygiene practices, says Lisa Maragakis, senior director of infection prevention in the Johns Hopkins Health System. If people wash their hands regularly and sneeze into their elbows, handshakes won’t be as risky.
  • Donald Trump praises Xi Jinping for his handling of the Covid-19 epidemic in China: Just had a long and very good conversation by phone with President Xi of China. He is strong, sharp and powerfully focused on leading the counterattack on the Coronavirus. He feels they are doing very well, even building hospitals in a matter of only days. Nothing is easy, but... ....he will be successful, especially as the weather starts to warm & the virus hopefully becomes weaker, and then gone. Great discipline is taking place in China, as President Xi strongly leads what will be a very successful operation. We are working closely with China to help!
  • Weller, Monica: Mongolia Braces for Coronavirus Impact, The Diplomat, 09.02.2020.
    Quote: In response to growing fears amid the spread of a novel strain of coronavirus, Mongolia shut down its borders to China and closed all schools and public gatherings until March 2. There are currently no confirmed cases of coronavirus in Mongolia, but the government has taken stringent measures to prevent the spread of disease.
  • Gramer, Robbie; Lynch, Colum: Trump Seeks to Halve U.S. Funding for World Health Organization as Coronavirus Rages, Foreign Policy, 10.02.2020.
    Quote: The Trump administration is eyeing steep cuts to global health funds in its 2021 budget proposal, slashing more than $3 billion in overall programs, including half of its annual funding to the World Health Organization (WHO), which is leading the fight against the deadly coronavirus outbreak.
  • Goldberg, Mark Leon: The Trump Administration Seeks Massive Cuts to the World Health Organization and UN Peacekeeping. Also, the Total Elimination of Funding for UNICEF, UN Dispatch, 11.02.2020.
    Quote: The budget request released this week by the White House recommends large cuts to US payments to several United Nations entities. This includes a 53% cut to the World Health Organization, which is at the front line of responding to two major global emergencies: the Wuhan Coronavirus outbreak and the ebola outbreak in the Democratic Republic of the Congo.
  • Gorbalenya, Alexander E., et al: Severe acute respiratory syndrome-related coronavirus: The species and its viruses – a statement of the Coronavirus Study Group, bioRxiv, 11.02.2020.
    The Coronavirus Study Group (CSG) of the International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses formally recognizes this virus as a sister to severe acute respiratory syndrome coronaviruses (SARS-CoVs) of the species Severe acute respiratory syndrome-related coronavirus and designates it as severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2). (Paper available as PDF released under the terms of the CC-BY-NC-ND 4.0 International license. See local copy of the paper by Gorbalenya et al (PDF).)
  • Coronavirus disease named Covid-19, BBC News, 11.02.2020.
    The WHO named the disease caused by the coronavirus Covid-19. The International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses named the virus itself SARS-CoV 2.
  • WHO on Twitter, 11.02.2020: "Having a name matters to prevent the use of other names that can be inaccurate or stigmatizing. It also gives us a standard format to use for any future coronavirus outbreaks"-@DrTedros #COVID19
  • Transcript for CDC Telebriefing: CDC Update on Novel Coronavirus, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 12.02.2020.
  • Spencer, Saranac Hale: Fake Coronavirus Cures, Part 3: Vitamin C Isn’t a Shield, FactCheck.org, 12.02.2020.
  • Cohen, Joshua: COVID-19: Why Names Of New Infectious Diseases Matter, Forbes, 13.02.2020.
  • Beijing fuming after Taiwan joins WHO forum under the name ‘Taipei’ (民視英語新聞 Formosa TV English News on YouTube, 13.02.2020).
    Video description: With the support of its allies, Taiwan was able to join a World Health Organization meeting this week on COVID-19. Under the designation of "Taipei," Taiwanese public health experts participated in the closed-door technical meeting by videoconference. (…) In a remote press briefing, Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman Geng Shuang said China had given approval for Taiwan experts to join in a personal capacity, on the basis of the “One China” principle. He said the DPP had conducted “despicable” political manipulation that resulted in the experts joining under the name “Taipei.” Even in an epidemic, asserting Taiwan claims seems to still be at the top of China’s priorities.
  • CDC: Some Coronavirus Testing Kits Sent to States Are Faulty Drugs.com, 13.02.2020.
    Quote: Some coronavirus testing kits sent to state laboratories across the United States are flawed and do not provide accurate results, the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said Wednesday.
  • Yau, Cannix: How to make your own mask: Hong Kong scientists reveal temporary solution for those unable to get protective gear because of panic buying and price-gouging, South China Morning Post (SCMP), 14.02.2020.
  • Everington, Keoni: Update: Rise in sulfur dioxide could be sign of mass cremations in Wuhan, Taiwan News, 15.02.2020.
    Quotes: [Peng Chi-ming] said that cremations of human corpses would produce more in the way of nitrogen oxides (NOx) than SO2. Peng added that even if coal, gas, or oil was used to burn the bodies, it would be unlikely to produce such a large concentration of sulfur dioxide.
    A staffer from a funeral home in Wuhan, the epicenter of the novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) outbreak, claims the number of bodies she and her co-workers have had to transport and cremate each day is four to five times higher than the usual amount. Based on the account of the Wuhan funeral home staffer, the daily average number of bodies suspected of being coronavirus victims is estimated at 225, or 4,725 bodies, at a single Wuhan funeral home since Jan. 22.
  • Wetsman, Nicole: The US has its first case of the new Wuhan coronavirus, The Verge, 21.02.2020.
  • Coronavirus: Lebanon confirms first case, imported from Iran, The Straits Times, 21.02.2020.
    Quote: Lebanon confirmed its first coronavirus case on Friday (Feb 21), a 45-year-old woman who had arrived from Iran and was being quarantined in a Beirut hospital.
  • Hamblin, James: You’re Likely to Get the Coronavirus, The Atlantic, 24.02.2020.
  • Shi Jiangtao; Orange Wang; Kristin Huang; Linda Lew: Coronavirus: Wuhan eases lockdown then U-turns 3 hours later, while China’s daily deaths rise 55 per cent, South China Morning Post, 24.02.2020.
  • Yang, Xiaobo; Yu, Yuan; Xu, Jiqian; Shu, Huaqing; Xia, Jia'an; Liu, Hong, et al: Clinical course and outcomes of critically ill patients with SARS-CoV-2 pneumonia in Wuhan, China: a single-centered, retrospective, observational study, The Lancet, 24.02.2020.
  • Iran announces 50 dead in Qom coronavirus outbreak, The Times of Israel, 24.02.2020.
  • Woodward, Aylin: China just banned the trade and consumption of wild animals. Experts think the coronavirus jumped from live animals to people at a market., Business Insider, 25.02.2020.
    Quote: On Monday, the nation’s legislature banned the buying, selling, and eating of wild animals in an effort to prevent zoonotic diseases from jumping from animals to people.
  • Imbert, Fred: Larry Kudlow says US has contained the coronavirus and the economy is holding up nicely, CNBC, 25.02.2020.
    Larry Kudlow, director of the National Economic Council, claimed that, We have contained this. I won’t say [it’s] airtight, but it’s pretty close to airtight.
  • Baragona, Justin: Larry Kudlow Claims America Has ‘Contained’ Coronavirus: ‘Pretty Close to Airtight’, Daily Beast, 25.02.2020.
    Quote: With financial markets tumbling for the second straight day amid coronavirus fears and top U.S. health officials warning Americans to be prepared for the spread of the disease, Trump economic adviser Larry Kudlow insisted on Tuesday afternoon that the United States government has everything under control.
  • Lomazzi, Marc: Coronavirus : «L’année du Lion», ce roman qui avait prédit l’épidémie, Le Parisien, 25.02.2020.
    The novel L'année du lion by Deon Meyer was published in 2017 and is set an South-Africa after an corona epidemic has killed 90% of the population.
  • Palma, Bethania: Did Trump Administration Fire the US Pandemic Response Team?, Snopes, 26.02.2020, updated 13.03.2020.
    In the spring of 2018, Trump's government fired the executive branch team responsible for coordinating a response to a pandemic and did not replace it. See the article Top White House official in charge of pandemic response exits abruptly (Washington Post, 10.05.2020). According to A / @callisti2024 on Twitter, 12.03.2020, It is accurate. Bolton is the one who actually did it, but yes, the head of the pandemic response team resigned & Bolton disbanded the team. See the article below from May 2018.
    Claims of "defunding" or "reduced funding" are not accurate though.     (The “article below” is the article from The Washington Post, above.)
    See also Top White House official in charge of pandemic response exits as global health security team disbanded (by Lena H. Sun, The Independent, 11.05.2018).
  • Agamben, Giorgio: coronavirus et état d’exception, ACTA, 26.02.2020.
    French translation of an opinion piece originally publilshed in Italian in the communist publication il manifesto. For an English translation, see The coronaviris and the state of exception (03.03.2020).
  • Mahbubani, Rhea: Followers of the doomsday church cult that is linked to South Korea’s coronavirus outbreak were meeting in Wuhan until December, Business Insider, 26.02.2020.
  • De Santis, Raffaella: Libri, effetto coronavirus: in classifica tornano “La peste” e “Cecità”, la Repubblica, 27.02.2020.
    Sales of Albert Camus' novel La Peste and José Saramago's novel Blindness increased in Italy.
  • Kim, Arin: Drive-thru clinics, drones: Korea’s new weapons in virus fight, The Korea Herald, 27.02.2020, updated 28.02.2020.
    The city of Goyang, Gyeonggi Province, set up a drive-through facility where the process of checking for symptoms, collecting a sample and paying can be handled in 10 minutes. The service would soon be expanded to other cities. Companies were also developing at-home testing kits but these had not been verified.
  • Was das Coronavirus in der Lunge anrichtet, wissenschaft.de, 28.02.2020.
  • Wright, Robin: How Iran Became a New Epicenter of the Coronavirus Outbreak, The New Yorker, 28.02.2020.
  • Partly false claim: a 1981 book predicted the coronavirus 2019 outbreak, Reuters, 28.02.2020.
  • Miranda, Leticia: Face masks are not the best protection against the virus — but that's not stopping the scammers, NBC, 28.02.2020.
    Face masks have become much more expensive, for example on Amazon and Walmart. However, as a protection measure for the general public, the WHO recommends handwashing instead of wearing masks. Quote: Michael Ryan, the executive director of the WHO Health Emergencies Program, addressed the use of face masks during a media briefing. The WHO stance regarding surgical masks being worn by the general public is that only those who are already sick with a respiratory illness should wear them, he said.
  • FACT CHECK: Did Trump Call The Coronavirus A ‘Hoax’ At His South Carolina Rally?, CheckYourFact, 29.02.2020.
    This article examines a claim by Politico that Trump had called the novel coronavirus a hoax. CheckYourFact comes to a different conclusion: Trump referred to the alleged “politicizing” of the coronavirus by Democrats as “their new hoax.” He did not refer to the coronavirus itself as a hoax. The Hill, the Daily Beast and Slate, among other outlets, reported that the “hoax” comment was talking about Democratic criticism.
  • Die Coronavirus-Pandemie in Bayern - die Monate Januar und Februar, Süddeutsche Zeitung, 29.02.2020.

March 2020

2 March 2020

  • Wood, Zoe: Amazon struggles to halt tide of coronavirus profiteers, The Guardian, 02.03.2020.
  • First Brit to Contract Coronavirus Reveals His Experience (This Morning, 10 minutes, 02.03.2020). Connor Reed lives in Wuhan as a teacher and caught Corona at the end of November 2019. He explains he went through three stages: at first it is like a common cold, then it begins to feel like the flu and finally it feels like pneumonia. He believes that the figures released by the Chinese government are accurate, even though some hospitals initially tried to cover it up.
    Professor Paul Hunter is much less optimistic than in January that the epidemic can be controlled. He expects it will go on into the Summer; it is not clear yet whether it will come back in the Winter, but there may be a vaccine by then. It is not clear yet whether you become immune (for some time) after you've been infected.
  • Grim, Ryan; Chávez, Aída: How the Senate Paved the Way for Coronavirus Profiteering, and How Congress Could Undo It, The Intercept, 02.03.2020.

    Quotes: President Trump and Dr. Anthony Fauci, the director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, participated in a roundtable briefing at the National Institutes of Health Vaccine Research Center Tuesday afternoon amid fears over the spread of the coronavirus in the United States and around the world. Top health officials said the current timeline for a vaccine's availability to the public is likely the end of this year or beginning of next.

4 March 2020

    The relevant study is Community Transmission of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus 2, Shenzhen, China, 2020 (early release in Emerging Infectious Diseases, Volume 26, Number 6—June 2020).
  • Tang, Abby; Yan, Michelle; Appolonia, Alexandria: Pathologists debunk 13 myths about the coronavirus, including why masks won't help, Business Insider, 04.03.2020.
    An N95 mask is able to filter particles that are airborne with 95% efficacy. Other masks provide less protection, especially when not worn properly, and may people untrained in wearing them a false sense of security.

  • Woodward, Aylin: Between 40% and 70% of adults worldwide could get the coronavirus, one Harvard expert says. That’s at least 3 billion cases., Business Insider, 05.03.2020.
    Quote: Harvard epidemiologist Marc Lipsitch told the Deep Background podcast that the coronavirus could become a pandemic that affects between 40% and 70% of the world’s adult population – at least 3 billion people. Note that these estimations assume that governments don't take strong countermeasures. The virus's spread can be halted by isolating and quaratining people who are infected with the virus. The article also adds, According to Lipsitch, infections or inoculations in 40% to 50% of the world’s adult population would be enough to stymie the virus‘ spread.

11 March 2020

  • Edward, Debi: The lessons and mistakes Italy can learn from China on how to deal with coronavirus outbreak, ITV News, 11.03.2020.
  • Brennan, Cianan: The three stages of Ireland's coronavirus control plan explained, Irish Examiner, 11.03.2020.
  • Corona-Update #11: Wir müssen jetzt gezielt handeln (NDR Ratgeber on YouTube, 30 minutes, 11.03.2020). Interview with Christian Drosten, virologist at the Charité in Berlin, Germany.
  • Shaikh, Alanna: Coronavirus Is Our Future (TEDxSMU) (TEDx Talks on YouTube, 17 minutes, 11.03.2020).
  • Engels, Trui: Welke coronamaatregelen neemt de overheid? Een overzicht, Knack, 11.03.2020, updated 13.03.2020.
    Overview of measures taken by the Belgian government. The government initially banned all indoor events with more than 1,000 particpants, later expanding this to all events. Visits to retirement homes are prohibited. In schools, classes are suspended but schools still need to take care of the children. Several universities switch over to telecommuting for their employees and distance learning for their students. Restaurants, pubs and discos must close, but delivery of food and meals is still allowed. Hotels can remain open but their restaurants must close. Shops must close on weekends except those that delilver essesntial services, i.e. pharmacies and shops that sell food. Companies are allowed to remain productive but are advised to rely more an telecommuting and flexible working hours. Public transport can still be used, the ideally not during rush hours and only when necessary. Elderly people are asked to stay at home as much as possible.
  • D'Amore, Rachael: What does it take to recover from coronavirus? It depends, experts say, MSN, 11.03.2020.
    For serious cases, according to Dr. Jason Kindrachuk, Basically, what people need to recover, based on everything we know right now, is just a fairly robust immune system. That's our best guess. Also: Both Kindrachuk and Bogoch agree that those who recover from mild COVID-19 cases are unlikely to see lingering health issues, but it's too soon to say what lasting impacts the virus will have on those who recover from more serious cases. However, patients who ended up in intensive care units during the 2002-03 SARS outbreak, suffered quite a bit of lung damage. Many ended up with pulmonary fibrosis, which is essentially the scarring of lung tissue. (...) hat alone brings complications because it, unfortunately, doesn't resolve.

  • Pearson, Catherine: Can You Get Coronavirus Again After You've Already Had It?, HuffPost, 12.03.2020.
    Quote: Dr. Peter Jung, an assistant professor of pediatrics at the University of Texas Medical School at Houston, weighed in on the possibility of reinfection in children: “No one knows for sure, but most children likely develop at least short-term immunity to the specific coronavirus that causes COVID-19,” he said. “But just as the flu can mutate, so could COVID-19, which would make an individual susceptible to reacquiring the infection.”
    Other experts feel it is far more likely that once an individual has contracted COVID-19, they will not be able to get it again.

According to her calculations, coronavirus testing would cost a citizen a minimum of $1,331. She pressed a member of the administration to commit to making all testing immediately free and he conceded Dr. Redfield of the CDC tried to avoid to committing to using his authority to enable this testing for all Americans. One week earlier, Katie Porter and two other members of Congress had already written a letter to Dr. Redfield explaining the issue, pointing out that he had the authority to take that decision.

14 March 2020

  • Wegen Coronavirus: Fast alle Länder schließen Schulen und Kitas, tagesschau, 14.03.2020.
    Saarland was the first German state to close its schools. Hamburg initially closed its schools until 29 March. Hessen decided to (temporarily) repeal compulsory schooling. Sachsen-Anhalt closed its schools until 13 April; other states typically until 19/20 April.

    Quote: Op de luchthaven van Luik is vrijdagavond een vliegtuig geland met aan boord bijna 500.000 mondmaskers en ander medisch materiaal. Die zijn door de stichtingen van de Chinese internetgigant Alibaba en zijn oprichter Jack Ma geschonken aan Europa.
  • Thompson, Derek: America Is Acting Like a Failed State, The Atlantic, 14.03.2020.
    Quote: Throughout the world, the most effective responses to the historic threat of the coronavirus have come from state governments. (…)
    But in the United States, the pandemic has devolved into a kind of grotesque caricature of American federalism. The private sector has taken on quasi-state functions at a time when the executive branch of government—drained of scientific expertise, starved of moral vision—has taken on the qualities of a failed state.
    See also The Atlantic: America Is Acting Like A Failed State (MSNBC on YouTube, 9 minutes, 12.04.2020). Stephanie Ruhle of MSNBC talks with David Brooks of the New York Times and Eddie Glaude of Center for African-American Studies. Eddie Glaude points that in many places in the USA, 60–70% of Covid-19 deaths are African-Americans.

16 March 2020

  • Payne, Adam: Spain has nationalized all of its private hospitals as the country goes into coronavirus lockdown, Business Insider, 16.03.2020.
    Spain declared a state of emergency (on 13 March), mobilised the military and decided to put off of the country's private healtcare providers under public control. In addition, fourth-year medical students would be asked to aid the country's health service.
  • Jacobs, Inge: Stuttgarter Hochschulen müssen alle Prüfungen absagen, Stuttgarter Zeitung, 16.03.2020.
    Quote: Um das Risiko einer Ansteckung mit dem Coronavirus möglichst gering zu halten, müssen alle Hochschulen im Land ihren Studienbetrieb bis 19. April komplett runterfahren. Das hat das Wissenschaftsministerium am 16. März per Rechtsverordnung verfügt.
  • In diesem Berliner Bezirk gibt es die meisten Corona-Infizierten, B.Z. Berlin, 16.03.2020.
    Charlottenburg-Wilmersdorf had the highest number of infections (54), followed by Mitte (45), Steglitz-Zehlendorf (34), Friedrichshain-Kreuzberg (30), Tempelhof-Schöneberg (27), Pankow (26), Neukölln (21), Reinickendorf (11), Marzahn-Hellersdorf (10), Spandau (9), Lichtenberg (8) and Treptow-Köpenick (8). Knapp 14 Prozent der Infizierten sind zwischen 30 und 39 Jahre alt. Das liegt wohl unter anderem daran, dass es viel Verbreitung des Virus über einen Club im Westteil Berlins gab. There were 94 cases in Brandenburg. There were no known Covid-19 infections in Frankfurt an der Oder, Ostprignitz-Ruppin, Prignitz or Uckermark.
  • Begley, Sharon: The new coronavirus can likely remain airborne for some time. That doesn’t mean we’re doomed, STAT, 16.03.2020.
  • Li, Ruiyum; Pei, Sen; Chen, Bin; Song, Yimeng; Zhang, Tao; Yang, Wan; Shaman, Jeffrey: Substantial undocumented infection facilitates the rapid dissemination of novel coronavirus (SARS-CoV2), Science, 16.03.2020.
  • Sawall, Achim: Ausgangssperre: Festnetz und Mobilfunk in Spanien wegen Corona überlastet, golem.de, 16.03.2020.
    Quote: Die Telefónica Spain hat angesichts von Millionen Menschen im Homeoffice und Tele Learning zu einer vernünftigen Nutzung von Mobilfunk und Festnetz aufgerufen. Das gab die Telefónica am 15. März 2020 bekannt.
  • Yong, Ed: The U.K.’s Coronavirus ‘Herd Immunity’ Debacle, The Atlantic, 16.03.2020.
  • Stieb, Matt: U.K. Only Grasped in the ‘Last Few Days’ It Had the Exact Wrong Coronavirus Plan, Intelligencer, 16.03.2020.
    Public-health experts had questioned the UK's plan to deal with the epidemic by slowing but not necessarily stopping epidemic spread. The plan consisted in allowing the virus to spread younger age groups, who are said to be less at risk for developing serious health problems, while protecting the old and the immunocompromised. However, relying on herd immunity, which would cost around 250,000 in the UK, turned out to be unfeasible. For this reason, the UK will take measures similar to those in other countries, relying on social distancing, isolation of infected individuals, and school and university closures.
  • Gaynor, Jessie: The first lines of 10 classic novels, rewritten for social distancing, Literary Hub, 16.03.2020.
  • Halliday, Josh: eBay urged to clamp down on coronavirus profiteering, The Guardian, 16.03.2020.
  • Rossman, Jeremy: Donald Trump thinks warm weather will stop coronavirus—here’s why he’s wrong, Prospect, 16.03.2020.
    Quote: The idea that the approaching spring may stem the spread of the disease comes largely from a comparison with the flu. (…) But the transmissibility and severity of COVID-19 are much greater than the flu. And it isn’t clear if COVID-19 transmission will be affected by seasonal temperature variation.
  • Belgische koning Filip regelt mondmaskers uit China, Nederlands Dagblad, 16.03.2020.
    Quote: Mede dankzij “de persoonlijke tussenkomst van de koning” ontvangt België deze week een schenking uit China van een half miljoen mondmaskers en 30.000 testkits voor de strijd tegen Covid-19. Het materiaal wordt geschonken door de Alibaba Foundation en de Jack Ma Foundation, schrijft de Belgische minister van Volksgezondheid Maggie De Block op haar website.

    Wittenberg, who is a languages student at the University of Cambridge, writes, with this outbreak predicted to peak during exam season, using venues of any size seems implausible, while rearranging exams for as late as the autumn would be equally unrealistic for students expecting to graduate in June.

    (See the study by Imperial College, London, 16.03.2020.)

    The measures being taken in the USA don't come near by those recommended by a study by Imperial College (London). Based on what is currently being done, the death toll in the USA might end up between 1.1 and 1.5 million.

18 March 2020

  • Coronavirus: Telekom schickt Handydaten an Robert-Koch-Institut, Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung, 18.03.2020 (last update).
    German telecom provider Deutsche Telekom provided a dataset of 5 gigabyte anonymised customer data to the Robert-Koch-Institut in order to allow the analysis of movement data and extrapolations about the spread of the Covid-19 epidemic. The process was development in co-operation with data protection authorities and approved by the federal Datenschutzbeauftragter in 2015.
    In Austria, telecom provider A1 handed over similar data to a spinoff of the TU Graz.
  • felix stalder / @stalfel: Should we use mobile phone data to trace the spread of the virus and monitor public health efforts?
    A mini thread!    . (Twitter, 18.03.2020).
  • Agamben, Giorgio: Nach Corona: Wir sind nurmehr das nackte Leben, Neue Zürcher Zeitung, 18.03.2020.
  • ‘We’re not ready for the next epidemic’ — Bill Gates has been warning us about a catastrophic virus for years, Now This on Twitter, 18.03.2020.
  • 25,000 perform 'Khatme Shifa' to fight coronavirus in Lakshmipur, Dhaka Tribune, 18.03.2020.
    Quote: At least 25,000 people performed a prayer named Khatme Shifa or Ayat ash-Shifa (Six Quranic Verses of Healing) to seek the containment of the pandemic Covid-19 at the Central Eidghah of Lakshmipur's Raipur. (…) This happened at a time when the government has been routinely urging people to avoid public gathering as a precaution to protect all from the Covid-19 pandemic.
  • Stolper, Daniel: Corona versus Datenschutz?, datenschutz-notizen, 18.03.2020.
  • Italiaanse artsen strijden tegen corona: "Het maakt ons kapot" (Terzake on YouTube, 6 minutes, 18.03.2020).
  • Scott, Dylan: Trump’s new fixation on using a racist name for the coronavirus is dangerous, Vox, 18.03.2020.
  • "Hey, philosophy department, how does it feel without your students around?" (Swarthmore Philosophy on Twitter, 18.03.2020).
  • Wilson, Reid: CDC analysis shows coronavirus poses serious risk for younger people, The Hill, 18.03.2020.
    Quote: A new CDC analysis of more than 2,400 cases of COVID-19 that have occurred in the United States in the last month shows that between 1 in 7 and 1 in 5 people between the ages of 20 and 44 in the sample of those who are confirmed cases require hospitalization, a level significantly higher than the hospitalization rates for influenza. The true percentage of young people who require hospitalization is likely much less, because many remain asymptomatic.
    See also COVID-19 Poses SERIOUS Health Risk to Young People Too, CDC Data Suggests (The Humanist Report on YouTube, 9 minutes, 20.03.2020.
  • Raab, Klaus: Sind Medien in Krisenzeiten kritisch genug?, MDR.DE, 18.03.2020.
  • Corona: Merkel wendet sich in Fernsehansprache an die Deutschen, Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung, 18.03.2020.
  • Batty, David: Cambridge students urge university to let them retake the final year, The Guardian, 18.03.2020.
  • 'Vaccines won't work': US virologist breaks down COVID-19, how to curb spread (THE KOREA TIMES 코리아타임스 on YouTube, 16 minutes, 18.03.2020).
    This video is an interview with Dr. Hakim Djaballah, CEO of Keren Therapeutics and ex-CEO of Pasteur Institute Korea. Dajaballah says that after SARS 1 and MERS, SARS-CoV-2 is the third virus coronavirus that has crossed from animals to humans. With these viruses, we are in uncharted territory. The fast spread of the virus in China was very unusual; this virus is more aggressive and more lethal. For every virus, there is a certain is a lethal dose, in this case how much of the virus you need to have in your lungs before it makes you sick or kills you. We don't know the lethal dose for SARS-CoV-2. In addition, there have been reports of people who were cured and then got reinfected. The tests we do can only test a certain limit; below a certain threshold of violence, nothing will be detected and the patient will be declared healthy enough to be released from hospital. The virus is still very mysterious. It does not only attack the lungs but also the heart and the liver.
    Among young people, the rate of infection is lower than with MERS. China is not very forthcoming with information; this is not primarily important for the development of a vaccine but for detecting patterns. Even if we had a vaccine today, it wouldn't help. Vaccines don't work for every individual that gets the vaccine. A vaccine is a preventative measure: it prepares your immune system [and it is the immune system that protects you]. The most important piece of information from China that is missing is Patient Zero; this information would be critical in helping virologists understand the evolution of the virus. It would also help stop the spread. Information about Patient Zero would help virologists understand “advantageous mutations” that happened when the virus managed to jump from the animal kingdom to humans. This information is important for the development of an effective vaccine.
    Companies and researchers have been trying to develop a vaccine for SARS-CoV-1 for [almost] 20 years now and it is still not available. One of the reasons is that the threat of SARS-CoV-1 has gone. Another reason is that they have identified difficulties that these viruses are not immunable [amenable?] to a vaccine.
    The only reason why we have a vaccine for Ebola is that Ebola decided to leave Africa and started infecting people in Europe and America, so governments provided funding for development of a vaccine. Companies don't develop vaccines if there is nobody to buy them. However, there has not yet been a similar push for the development of a SARS vaccine.
    This virus uses bacteria to spread, and airplanes are excellent environments for spreading bacteria. The virus that landed in Italy is more aggressive than the one that left from China, due to mutations.
    Masks help lower the spread of the infection because wearers are less likely to touch their face. (…)
  • Team NEXT IAS: Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) test for COVID-19, NEXT IAS — Current Affairs Blog, 18.03.2020.
    A description of the steps from saliva sample to test result.
  • Trump Dubs COVID-19 'Chinese Virus' Despite Hate Crime Risks, US News, 18.03.2020.
  • Cuba can produce 23 drugs to treat coronavirus, working on a vaccine against it, ¡ahora!, 18.03.2020.
  • Gaurav, Kunal: Study Predicts 2.2 Million Coronavirus Deaths In US, Half A Million In UK, Republicworld.com (India), last updated on 18.03.2020.
    Quote: In the modelling study led by Neil Ferguson, professor of mathematical biology at Imperial College London, the researchers used the gathered from Italy to project the impact of the pandemic if positive interventions are not made at the earliest. The team predicted the two possible scenarios of the impact depending on the intensity of the interventions and combinations.

19 March 2020

  • Sokol, Sam: Ultra-Orthodox in Israel ignoring social distancing: ‘We’re not scared', The Jerusalem Post, 19.03.2020.
  • We still have to laugh to keep our spirits up: (Patricia Churchland on Twitter, 19.03.2020). Cartoon showing four death figures on horseback (like the four horsemen of the Apocalypse), one of whom is carrying several packages of toilet paper. One of the other death figures asks, Seriously?
  • Do the five, Twitter, 19.03.2020.

    The World Health Organization is advising people to follow five simple steps to help prevent the spread of COVID-19:

    1. Wash your hands
    2. Cough/sneeze into your elbow
    3. Don't touch your face
    4. Stay more than 3ft (1m) away from others
    5. Stay home if you feel sick
  • Police officers in India made a viral video to teach proper hygiene amid the coronavirus outbreak (QuickTake by Bloomberg on Twitter, 19.03.2020).
  • Der Tag: Streit um Klopapier eskaliert - Zwei Verletzte in Supermarkt, n-tv.de, 19.03.2020.
  • Mak, Tim: Intelligence Chairman Raised Virus Alarms Weeks Ago, Secret Recording Shows, NPR, 19.03.2020.
    Quote: The chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee warned a small group of well-connected constituents three weeks ago to prepare for dire economic and societal effects of the coronavirus, according to a secret recording obtained by NPR.
  • Fang, Lee: Banks Pressure Health Care Firms to Raise Prices Amid Coronavirus Crisis, The Intercept, 19.03.2020.
  • Pueyo, Tomas: Coronavirus: The Hammer and the Dance — What the Next 18 Months Can Look Like, if Leaders Buy Us Time, @tomaspueyo on Medium, 19.03.2020 (27-minute read).
  • Lordon, Frédéric: « Les connards qui nous gouvernent », Les blogs du Diplo, 19.03.2020.
    Quote:

    Jusqu’ici, les morts du capitalisme néolibéral, entre amiante, scandales pharmaceutiques, accidents du travail, suicides France Télécom, etc., étaient trop disséminés pour que la conscience commune les récapitule sous un système causal d’ensemble. Mais ceux qui arrivent par wagons, on ne les planquera pas comme la merde au chat. (…)

    En réalité, une pandémie du format de celle d’aujourd’hui est le test fatal pour toute la logique du néolibéralisme. Elle met à l’arrêt ce que ce capitalisme demande de garder constamment en mouvement frénétique.

  • How Long The COVID-19 Coronavirus Lasts On Everyday Surfaces (Science Insider on YouTube, 3 minutes, 19.03.2020).
    SARS-CoV-2 is not airborne but can survive up to three hours in droplets in the air, on copper surfaces, the virus can survive up to four hours, on cardboard up to 24 hours (although it is unlikely that packages or mail can transmit the virus), on plastic and stainless steel the virus can survive two to three days (which is longer than the influenza virus). Researchers don't know yet how long the virus can survive on a phone or a phone case.
    To reduce the risk of exposure, do not touch your eyes, mouth and face, wash your hands with water and soap for at least 20 seconds, clean commonly used surfaces with disinfecting wipes and avoid non-essential travel to public places, especially at peak times.
  • Anderson, Elizabeth: Coronavirus in the UK: Pensioners may have to accept lower income or later retirement date as Covid-19 outbreak hits investments, inews, 19.03.2020.
  • Bort, Ryan: ‘Not Concerned at All’: A Timeline of Trump’s Coronavirus Dismissals , Rolling Stone, 19.03.2020.
  • Trevor Bedford / @trvrb: The second, related, strategy is using cell phone location data combined with data on known positive cases to alert possible exposures to self isolate and get tested. Figure from @ChristoPhraser and colleagues who've considered this in detail. 15/19 (Twitter, 19.03.2020).
    The thread also contains a link to Quantifying dynamics of SARS-CoV-2 transmission suggests that epidemic control and avoidance is feasible through instantaneous digital contact tracing on GitHub.
  • Freund, Alexander: Corona-Spätfolgen: Genesene haben teilweise reduzierte Lungenfunktion, DW, 19.03.2020.
    Serious cases of Covid-19 may have a reduced pulmonary function and lasting shortness of breath. It is not yet certain whether they also have pulmonary fibrosis. Most experts are convinced that people who have recovered from a SARS-CoV-2 infection are immune against the virus.
  • Rudl, Tomas: Standortdaten und Corona – Unverhofftes Datengeschenk, netzpolitik.org, 19.03.2020.
    After the Austrian telecom provider A1 handed over location data for analysis, the >German telecom provider Deutsche Telekom did something similar by handing over 5 gigabyte anonymised of anonymised location data to the Robert-Koch-Institut (RKI). However, it is not yet clear what would be done with the analysis of these data, nor whether they would be really helpful. Even the RKI does not know yet in what way the data might be useful.
    The German Data Protection Officer Ulrich Kelber claimed on Twitter that the data transfer was defensible from a legal point of view: Die Weitergabe von Standortdaten durch die Deutsche Telekom an das Robert-Koch-Institut @rki_de ist in der gewählten Form datenschutzrechtlich vertretbar. Vor allem unter den aktuellen Umständen spricht nichts gegen die Weitergabe dieser Daten zum Zweck des Gesundheitsschutzes. However, data experts agree that reliable anonymisation is hard to implement on the long term.
  • Peter, Tobias: FDP warnt vor Einschränkung der Bürgerrechte in der Coronakrise, Redaktionsnetzwerk Deutschland, 19.03.2020.
    Stephan Thomae of the FDP warned that important civil rights should not be sacrificed during the Covid-19 pandemic. Border closures, which require border checks, can slow down transport of goods and disrupt delivery chains. Thomae also warned against abandoning data protection, mentioning specifically the cell phone location data that Telekom handed over to the RKI. He warned against a slippery slope: if we hand over data in the fight against the Covid-19 epidemic, what will be the next goal that will be invoked?
  • Lohse, Eckart: Merkel: „Es ist ernst. Nehmen Sie es auch ernst“, Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung, 19.03.2020.
    Article about Chancellor Merkel's address to the German citizens.
  • Allegretti, Aubrey: Coronavirus: Students to get GCSE and A-level grades with no exams, Sky News, 19.03.2020.
  • Jabin Botsford / @jabinbotsford on Twitter, 19.03.2020: Close up of President @realDonaldTrump notes is seen where he crossed out "Corona" and replaced it with "Chinese" Virus as he speaks with his coronavirus task force today at the White House. #trump #trumpnotes

    Jabin Botsford is staff photographer at the The Washington Post.
  • Bailey, Alyssa: Lana Condor Called Trump Out for His Racist 'Chinese Virus' COVID-19 Rhetoric, Elle,19.03.2020.
  • Wie gut sind deutsche Krankenhäuser auf Corona vorbereitet?, MDR.DE, 19.03.2020.
  • Bacon, John: 75,000 ill, 2,000 deaths, many thousands recovered: Can you get coronavirus twice?, USA Today, 19.03.2020.
    Quote: Eng Eong Ooi, a professor of emerging infectious diseases at Singapore's Duke-NUS Medical School, told USA TODAY the data is too new to determine definitively whether the immunity will last for a very short period of time, for years or for life.
    "Inflammation appears to be a cause of severe COVID-19. It also helps in the development of immunity," he said. But "any conclusion will be premature, I fear. (We) will need studies."
  • Hydroxychloroquine reduces viral load in COVID-19 patients, Virology Blog, 19.03.2020.
  • Coronavirus : Le « journal de confinement » de Leïla Slimani suscite l’indignation sur Twitter, 20 Minutes, 19.03.2020.

20 March 2020

  • Ritschel, Chelsea: Coronavirus: Can you get Covid-19 twice or does it cause immunity?, The Independent, 20.03.2020.
    Quote: According to Li QinGyuan, director of pneumonia prevention and treatment at China Japan Friendship Hospital in Beijing, those who have been infected with Covid-19 develop a protective antibody - but it isn’t clear how long the protection lasts.
  • COVID-19: Prevention and Treatment, Vitamin C, California Institute for Human Science, 20.03.2020.
  • Salzberg, Steven: No, Megadoses Of Vitamin C Will Not Cure Coronavirus, Forbes, 20.03.2020.
  • Harari, Yuval Noah: Yuval Noah Harari: the world after coronavirus, Financial Times, 20.03.2020.
    Quote: In this time of crisis, we face two particularly important choices. The first is between totalitarian surveillance and citizen empowerment. The second is between nationalist isolation and global solidarity.
    Some countries, such as China and Israel, have deployed new surveillance tools. In other countries also, the Covid-19 epidemic may normalise the deployment of surveillance tools that governments or citizens have rejected until before the epidemic. Harari presents a hypothetical government that demands that every citizen wears a biometric bracelet that monitors body temperature and heart-rate 24 hours a day. However, the same biometric data that can track body temperature, heart rate and blood pressure can also track our emotions. Combined with the tracking of what we read online (especially on mobile devices) this would create a terrifying surveillance system. The problem with temporary measures is that they often result in permanent changes. Israel's 1948 War of Independence already provided an example of this. After the epidemic, governments may come up with arguments to keep the surveillance system in place.
    Harari says that asking people to choose between privacy and health is a false choice; we should be able to enjoy both. We can choose to protect our health and stop the coronavirus epidemic not by instituting totalitarian surveillance regimes, but rather by empowering citizens. Harari cites the examples of South Korea, Taiwan and Singapore. While these countries have made some use of tracking applications, they have relied far more on extensive testing, on honest reporting, and on the willing co-operation of a well-informed public. (…)
  • Smith-Meyer, Bjarke: EU finance ministers deadlock on coronavirus economic strategy, Politico, 20.03.2020.
    Southern European countries were hoping for a strategy similar to bailout fund or the creation of special “corona bonds”. However, other countries, especially from Northern Europe, [prefer] the option of opening credit lines from the European Stability Mechanism (ESM).
  • Städte- und Gemeindebund gegen Ausgangssperre, Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung, 20.03.2020.
    Since citizens generally obey the measures regarding mobility restrictions and social distancing, a complete curfew does not seem necassry. It would also be difficult to verify. In addition, it is better to instruct people than to force them.
  • Folgen der Coronakrise: Bald Hilfe für Solo-Selbständige, taz, 20.03.2020.
  • Ganz klare Ansage von Ministerpräsident #Kretschmann: „Wenn nicht alle ihr Verhalten jetzt grundlegend umstellen, dann kommen wir um härtere Maßnahmen und Sanktionen nicht herum.“ Halten Sie sich an die beschlossenen Maßnahmen. #stayhome #flattenthecurve #Covid_19 #Coronaparties, Landesregierung BW / @RegierungBW, 20.03.2020. Young people are still holding Corona parties and elderly people leisurely chat with each other on the market. If people don't change their behaviour, a curfew will be necessary.
    See also Aktuelle Infos zu Corona in Baden-Württemberg.
  • Doctor: As Coronavirus Cases Spike Worldwide, We Need Global Cooperation to Halt Spread (Democracy Now! on YouTube, 26 minutes, 20.03.2020).
    Interview with Michele Barry of the Center for Innovation in Global Health (CIGH) at Stanford University.
    22 minutes into the interview, she points out that this epidemic is not “the big one”; that would be a pandemic flu, which is airborne, whereas Covid-19 is droplet-borne.

    Continuation of the interview with Michele Barry. Also on the Democracy Now! website: “This Is a War,” Says Doctor on COVID-19. “We Are at the Beginning of a Surge, and It’s Terrifying.”
  • We Are INSANELY Unprepared for a Bigger Disaster (David Pakman Show on YouTube, 8 minutes, 20.03.2020).
  • Meister, Marina: Merkel und Macron: Die Coronakrise entzweit Paris und Berlin, Die Welt, 20.03.2020.
  • How to Save the U.S. Economy, With Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and Stephanie Kelton, The Intercept, 20.03.2020. (Podcast with transcript.)
  • Einschätzungen des Robert-Koch-Instituts vom 20. März (travelcamtv on YouTube, 9 minutes, 21.03.2020).
    Prof. Dr. Lothar H. Wieler, president of the Robert-Koch-Institut, answers various questions about the Corona epidemic, including differences with influenza. Covid-19 is more contagious than influenza, the percentage of infected people who develop a serious condition is higher, the percentage of infected high-risk people who need artificial respiration is considerably higher and the percentage of people in high-risk groups who die of the infectio is considerably higher. In influenza epidemics, children play a bigger role in spreading the virus, whereas, based on the current state of knowledge, all age groups infected with SARS-CoV-2 are equally contagious. In addition, there is no vaccine, nor medication, against SARS-CoV-2
  • Kroll, Andy: Broadcasting Trump’s Coronavirus Briefings Live Is a Danger to Public Health, Rolling Stone, 20.03.2020.
  • Greenberg, Jon: Timeline: How Donald Trump responded to the coronavirus pandemic, Politifact, 20.03.2020.
    This article provides an overview of Trump's reactions, many of them on Twitter, to the Covid-19 pandemic, starting 24 January 2020.

    Quote: The Trump administration announced Friday that states will be allowed to cancel federally mandated standardized tests in K-12 schools for the current year, as part of an ongoing disruption of familiar student performance measures caused by the coronavirus outbreak.

  • Linß, Vera: Journalismus in der Coronakrise – Berichten die Medien zu unkritisch?, Deutschlandfunk Kultur, 21.03.2020.
    According to Vera Linß, German media are too uncritical of the German government's measures. Often hey simply convey what the government announces or decrees, without questioning the curtailment of fundamental liberties and the discourse about surveillance. Especially the handing over of anonymised cellphone data to the Robert-Koch-Institut by telecom provider Deutsche Telekom was treated as part of the other reporting on the Covid-19 epidemic. Apparently, only netzpolitik.org was concerned that this might consitute a turning point in privacy.
  • Balzer, Vladimir: Coronavirus – Das widerstandslose Aufgeben der Freiheit ist gefährlich, Deutschlandfunk Kultur, 21.03.2020.
  • Loofbourow, Lili: The Real Reason Trump Started Calling the Virus “Chinese”, Slate, 21.03.2020.
    Quote:

    From a high-resolution photograph of Donald Trump’s printed-out remarks for his Thursday press conference, we know two things. The first is that Trump’s speech was printed out for him in a huge font and protected by a plastic page protector. The second was that the visible page of the speech was unmarked except in one place—where the word “Corona” in “Corona Virus” (two words) had been crossed out with a Sharpie and replaced with a word in distinctive penmanship printed in all caps: “CHINESE.”

    It was clear Trump had replaced the accepted shorthand for the COVID-19 virus with another that would blame another country for the pandemic while inflaming antipathy against the “Chinese” and (because ethnic hatreds aren’t especially discerning) Asians in general.
