23 March 2020

  • Waidenvoeller, Roman: Coronakrise: Eine Blutgruppe ist speziell betroffen, Zürcher Presse, 23.03.2020.
    According to Forbes, Chinese researchers who analysed data about deaths caused by Covid-19 have discovered that people with blood type 0 show more resistance against the virus, while people with blood type A show least resistance against an infection.
  • Applebaum, Anne: Coronavirus: COVID-19: The People in Charge See an Opportunity, The Atlantic, 23.03.2020.
  • Sacks, Brianna: A Man Died After Self-Medicating With A Drug Trump Promoted As A Potential Treatment For The Coronavirus, BuzzFeed News, 23.03.2020.
    Quote: The elderly man died after taking chloroquine phosphate, an additive used to clean fish tanks. Trump has been promoting chloroquine as a potential treatment for the coronavirus, but health officials say it hasn't been tested properly.
  • One Billion People Are In Quarantine In Homes All Around The World, Digital Phablet, 23.03.2020 (two-minute read).
    Quote: Approximately one billion people are restricted in their houses within 35 nations.
  • Krystal Ball: Suspend capitalism NOW, and do not resuscitate (The Hill on YouTube, 11 minutes, 23.03.2020.
    Journalist Krystall Ball points out that we see the capitalistic system crumbling, that the free market has failed and that 30% unemployment would be more than during the Great Depression (when it went up to 25 percent). By “suspending capitalism” she means things such as suspending debt collection, foreclosures, evictions and credit reports. She calls for the health care system to be nationalised.
    Memorable quotes: This economy was a daily crisis for mllions of Americans already, 40% of whom didn't have 400 dollars to cover an emergency, who live hand to mouth in the best of times. Now that daily crisis has transformed into a catastrophe for working America. and 30% unemployment isn't something you bootstrap and free-market your way through. It's something that our nation can only survive without mass chaos and unrest by truly embracing collectivism from the bottom to the top.
  • Collins, Donald A.: COVID-19 Means A Worldwide Lessening Of Religious Fantasy, Church and State, 23.03.2020.
    Quote: Religious fantasy can no longer be offered as a route to human survival. We humans are in charge and responsible.
  • Walker, Shaun: Hungary to consider bill that would allow Orbán to rule by decree, The Guardian, 23.03.2020.
    Quote: The bill seeks to extend the state of emergency declared earlier this month over coronavirus, and could also see people jailed for spreading information deemed to be fake news. The government has portrayed the move as a necessary response to the unprecedented challenges posed by the coronavirus pandemic, but critics immediately labelled the legislation as dangerously open-ended and vulnerable to abuse. The mandate that would be given to Orbán does not have a clear end date. Hungary had already been turning away from democrative standards before the Corona epidemic.
  • Mozingo, Joe: Why this Nobel laureate predicts a quicker coronavirus recovery: ‘We’re going to be fine’, Los Angeles Times, 23.03.2020.
    Stanford biophysicist Michael Levitt began analyzing the number of COVID-19 cases worldwide in January and correctly calculated that China would get through the worst of its coronavirus outbreak long before many health experts had predicted.
  • Lim, Louisa: China Is Trying to Rewrite The Present, Foreign Policy, 23.03.2020.
    Quote: Beijing is attempting to gaslight the world as it escalates its propaganda push to obscure the source of the disease. (…) Beijing’s arsenal includes a massive state-sponsored disinformation campaign, prominent “third-party spokespeople” and the expulsion of some of the most experienced American journalists in China.
  • Ezekiel J. Emanuel, M.D., Ph.D., Govind Persad, J.D., Ph.D., Ross Upshur, M.D., Beatriz Thome, M.D., M.P.H., Ph.D., Michael Parker, Ph.D., Aaron Glickman, B.A., Cathy Zhang, B.A., Connor Boyle, B.A., Maxwell Smith, Ph.D., and James P. Phillips, M.D.: Fair Allocation of Scarce Medical Resources in the Time of Covid-19, New England Journal of Medicine (Sounding Board), 23.03.2020.
    On 25 March, philosopher Daniel Dennett tweeted, If, as many predict, doctors and nurses will soon have to make terrible choices about who gets the ventilator and who dies, they should send Trump brief descriptions of the patients waiting in line and demand he make the decision. After all, his inaction caused the crisis. Byron Sebastian responded saying, That would be unethical. https://nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMsb2005114?fbclid=IwAR1kA7VMtv-G6ZX1N-xl1yMpqS_bOGosIk9ySNbhCGcUWkj7UNUuL9J-2MQ (His tweet contained a link to the above article.)
  • Keating, Steve; Kihara, Leika: Tokyo 2020 Games delay looms after U.S. joins calls for postponement, Reuters, 23.03.2020.
  • Donovan, Ryan: Defending yourself against coronavirus scams, Stack Overflow Blog, 23.03.2020.
  • Trump Caught Falling Asleep During Coronavirus Meeting (The Ring of Fire on YouTube, 5 minutes, 23.03.2020.
    In a meeting about the Coronavirus epidemic, Trump was so disinterested in what an expert was telling him (and probably tired) that he was visibly struggling to stay awake.
  • Schwartz, Adam; Crocker, Andrew: Governments Haven’t Shown Location Surveillance Would Help Contain COVID-19, Electronic Frontier Foundation, 23.03.2020.
    See also EFF's tweet, 30.03.2020: Before the public allows the implementation of location surveillance systems, governments must explain how such systems can contain the spread of COVID-19—and ground their reasoning in rigorous science.
  • Williams, Katie Bo: Why Trump Isn’t Using The Defense Production Act, Defense One, 23.03.2020.
    Willams's summary: He wants to allow corporations to sell vital medical gear to the highest-bidding states. Governors say that’s exactly the problem.
  • Brigham, Bob: Trump urges protection of Asian Americans — after weeks of using the racist term ‘Chinese Virus’, Raw Story, 23.03.2020.
  • Krisher, Tom; Yen, Hope: AP FACT CHECK: Trump hype on auto industry and ventilators, AP News, 23.03.2020.
    On 22 March, Donald Trump had tweeted, Ford, General Motors and Tesla are being given the go ahead to make ventilators and other metal products, FAST! @fema Go for it auto execs, lets see how good you are? @RepMarkMeadows @GOPLeader @senatemajldr However, according to AP, Neither GM or Ford is building ventilators at present, while Tesla CEO Elon Musk tweeted Friday that his company was “working on ventilators” but he didn’t specify how long it might take. His tweets also questioned the need and said it couldn’t be done immediately.
  • Trump baffles GM, Ford over ventilators they're willing to make, Chicago Business, 23.03.2020.
  • Breuninger, Kevin; Stankiewicz, Kevin: Trump advisor Larry Kudlow admits he was wrong about coronavirus being ‘contained’, CNBC, 23.03.2020.
    Quote: President Donald Trump’s top White House economic advisor, Larry Kudlow, said Monday that he no longer thinks the U.S. has the deadly coronavirus “contained,” as he said less than a month earlier.
  • Palma, Sky: Trump-loving pastors are telling their followers they can physically heal coronavirus with the power of prayer, Raw Story, 23.03.2020.
    Quote: One of those people is evangelist Kenneth Copeland, who, as the Daily Beast points out, visited the White House in 2018 for a dinner Trump held with a group of evangelical leaders. Earlier this month, Copeland went viral for a segment he did on his Victory Network channel where he asked his viewers to put their hands on their TV screens in order to receive God’s divine protection against the coronavirus.
  • De Decker, Nicholas: Quand Maggie De Block faisait détruire six millions de masques contre le coronavirus... sans les remplacer, Le Vif, 23.03.2020.
  • Walters, Greg: Trump Won't Rule Out Taking a Coronavirus Bailout to Save His Hotels. 'Let's Just See What Happens,' He Said., Vice, 23.03.2020.
  • België vernietigde vorig jaar stock FFP2-maskers, zonder ze te vervangen, Het Nieuwsblad, 23.03.2020.
    During or after the 2009 H1N1-flu epidemic, Belgium bought six million FFP2 masks. These masks reached their use-by date in 2019, so they were destroyed. For budgetary reasons, health minister Maggie De Block did not have the masks replaced. Belgium now faces shortages in medical protective equipment.

24 March 2020

  • Coronavirus: Under surveillance and confined at home in Taiwan, BBC, 24.03.2020.
    Milo Hsieh, an American student living in Taiwan under quarantine, said that his phone ran out of battery at 07:30 on a Sunday morning; by 08:20, two police officers were knocking on his door.
    See also Milo Hsieh's tweet (22.03.2020): My phone, which is satellite-tracked by the Taiwan gov to enforce quarantine, ran out of battery at 7:30 AM. By 8:15, four different units called me. By 8:20, the police were knocking at my door.
  • Costa-Font, Joan: Europe’s failure to address Covid-19 shows the need for a European ‘health citizenship’, London School of Economics and Political Science blog, 24.03.2020.
  • Taoiseach announces all non-essential shops to close, restrictions on gatherings of more than four people, thejournal.ie, 24.03.2020.
    In Ireland, all non-essential outlet stores, restaurants and cafes were told to close. Restaurants and cafes can still offer take-away food and drinks. Supermarket and pharmacies were allowed to remain open. (The article includes a full list of essential retail outlets as an image.)
  • Private hospitals will be made public for duration of coronavirus pandemic, thejournal.ie, 24.03.2020.
    The Irish government decided that private hospitals will act as part of the public health system for the duration of the coronavirus pandemic.
  • Coronavirus: Tokyo Olympics will be postponed, says IOC member Dick Pound, as window for 2021 Games opens, The Straits Times, 24.03.2020.
  • Lerner, Sharon; Fang, Lee: Coronavirus Treatment Developed by Gilead Sciences Granted “Rare Disease” Status, Potentially Limiting Affordability, The Intercept, 24.03.2020.
  • Economist Jeffrey Sachs: Trump “Understands Nothing, Listens to Nothing” as Pandemic Surges in U.S. (Democrac Now! on YouTube, 21 minutes, 24.03.2020).
    Jeffrey Sachs calls Donald Trump a complete nitwit who is endangering the American people. Trump is also unable to bring together and listen to competent people. State governors are on the front lines without federal support and the House of Representatives and the Senare are discussing which industries to rescue. In the mean time, East Asia (China, South Korea, Taiwan, Singapore) have used public health means to stop the spread of the virus. Sachs also comments on a statement by Dan Patrick, Texas Lieutenant Governor, who had said that there is no need for social distancing and that older people should sacrifice for the country's economy. The ignorance and cruelty displayed by some politicians almost leaves Jeffrey Sachs speechless.
  • Turse, Nick: Donald Trump Says America’s Ventilator Shortage Was “Unforeseen.” Nothing Could Be Further From the Truth. The Intercept, 24.03.2020.
    This article points out that many reports had warned about a shortage in medical equipment and supplies that would be needed for a large-scale epidemic. This includes reports by the Government Accountability Office (two reports from 2003), the Congressional Research Service (2005), the Congressional Budget Office (2006) and the Defence Department (2006).
  • Davis, Julia: Russia Swore It Whipped the Virus, and Fox and CNN Bought It, Daily Beast, 24.03.2020 (members-only content).
  • Murphy, Doyle: Missouri Walmart Coronavirus Licker Charged With 'Terrorist Threat', Riverfront Times, 24.03.2020.
    See also Peter Boghossian's tweet What do you think the penalty should be for the man who licked toiletries in a supermarket while asking, “who’s scared of coronavirus?” (25.03.2020).
  • Kuo, Lily: Ist das Virus wirklich besiegt?, Der Freitag, 24.03.2020.
    Even though Chinese authorities have partially lifted the curfew in Wuhan, analysts doubt that the infection rate in China is now really close to zero.
  • Durchdenwald, Thomas: OB Kuhn ordnet mehr Stadtbahnfahrten an, Stuttgarter Zeitung, 24.03.2020.
  • Nach Kritik wieder mehr Straßenbahnen in Stuttgart, SWR aktuell, 24.03.2020.
    The SSB in Stuttgart had reduced the number of buses and rapid transit trains (U-Bahn) so drastically that it had become almost impossible for passengers to maintain a distance of 1.5 metres to other people. This led to criticism; in response, SSB increased the frequency of the connections again.
  • A headline in the Financial Times today: "Coronavirus may have infected half of UK population — Oxford study". Remember that media headlines don't lend themselves to nuanced interpretations. A few words of caution..., Natalie E. Dean, PhD / @nataliexdean on Twitter, 24.03.2020.
  • Pulliam, Susan; Jones, Coulter, Fuller, Andrera: Amazon’s Bezos, Other Corporate Executives Sold Shares Just in Time, The Wall Street Journal, 24.03.2020 (pay-walled article).
    Quote: Top executives at U.S.-traded companies sold a total of roughly $9.2 billion in shares of their own companies between the start of February and the end of last week, a Wall Street Journal analysis shows.
  • Lippman, Daniel: DHS wound down pandemic models before coronavirus struck, Politico, 24.03.2020.
    Quote: The Department of Homeland Security stopped updating its annual models of the havoc that pandemics would wreak on America’s critical infrastructure in 2017, according to current and former DHS officials with direct knowledge of the matter.
  • Breuninger, Kevin: Trump wants ‘packed churches’ and economy open again on Easter despite the deadly threat of coronavirus, CNBC, 24.03.2020.
  • Historiker über Datenschutz in der Coronakrise – Wenn die Freiheit der Gesundheit geopfert wird, Deutschlandfunk Kultur, 24.03.2020.
    Inspired by the cell phone tracking practised in South Korea and the app used in Taiwan to reduced the spread of Covid-19, the German government considered including similar measures in its Infektionsschutzgesetz. Historian Andreas Rödder thinks we are getting used to restrictions to civil liberties that we would not have imagined before the start of the pandemic.
  • Le témoignage de Sacha Hasson, guéri du Covid-19 (BX1 on YouTube, 8 minutes, 24.03.2020).
  • Jameson, J. Larry: 7 Medical Leaders to Politicians: Save Lives, Not Wall Street, The New York Times, 24.03.2020.
  • Kiersz, Andy; Woodward, Aylin; Gould, Skye: One chart shows 10 countries' current coronavirus death rates, based on known cases and deaths. Italy's is highest: nearly 10%., Business Insider, 24.03.2020.
  • Mongelli, Lorena; Golding, Bruce: New York hospitals treating coronavirus patients with vitamin C, New York Post, 24.03.2020.
  • Wegen Friseur-Verbot: So sehen unsere Politiker in vier Wochen aus , Der Postillon, 24.03.2020.
  • Erica Fleming / @EricaHome1 on Twitter, 24.03.2020 Funniest thing I’ve watched since the #CoronaOutbreak #COVIDー19 The tweet contains a video in which a mother sings about the social distancing and the consequence of being confined at home.
  • CORONAVIRUS: Le conseil des ministres révélé (Discord Insoumis on YouTube, 4 minutes, 24.03.2020).

25 March 2020

  • Spanhel, Hanna; Zintz, Klaus: Ansteckung mit dem Coronavirus: Wie gut schützt ein selbst genähter Mundschutz?, Stuttgarter Zeitung, 25.03.2020.
  • Leutheusser-Schnarrenberger, Sabine: Corona-Maßnahmen: Wir sind zu schnell bereit, unsere Freiheit zu opfern, WELT, 25.03.2020.
  • Everington, Keoni: WHO ignored Taiwan's warnings about coronavirus in December, Taiwan News, 25.03.2020.
    Quote: Taiwan's Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) on Tuesday (March 24) confirmed that it had warned the World Health Organization (WHO) about the human-to-human transmission of the Wuhan coronavirus (COVID-19) in December of last year.
  • Fazeli, Yaghoub: Coronavirus spread to Qom through Chinese nationals: Iranian health ministry official, Al Arabiya English, 25.03.2020.
  • Frontline NY Nurses Lack Protective Masks & Ventilators, Say Worst Yet to Come as COVID-19 Spreads (Democracy Now! on YouTube, 19 minutes, 25.03.2020).
    According to this video, Almost half the cases in New York are among people between the ages of 18 and 45 years in age. Due to shortages, nurses need to use their protective masks for several days, which is something that would be totally inacceptable in normal circumstances. The video also contains an excerpt in which governor Andrew Cuomo points out that FEMA was sending him 400 ventilators although he needs 30.000 of them.
  • Republicans Collectively Agree to Sacrifice Your Grandma to the Gods of Capitalism (The Humanist Report, 19 minutes, 25.03.2020).
    Donald Trump said in a press briefing that he is willing to sacrifice the lives of elderly people in order to save the econonmy. Other Republicans have made similar statement, including Texas Lieutenant Governor Dan Patrick. However, it is not their own lives they want to sacrifice, but the lives of ordinary elderly citizens. Mike Figueredo says people should go on strike against this policy, which sacrifices lives for the sake of capitalism and the stock market.
  • Petersen, Volker: Covid-19 und die Statistik: Sorgen müssen sich auch die Jüngeren, n-tv.de, 25.03.2020.
    Earlier news reports had claimed that mainly the elderly and those with previouos medical conditions were at risk. Statistics published by the Robert-Koch-Institut show that the majority of persons infected with SARS-CoV-2 are aged between 15 and 59. However, out of the 114 deaths caused by the virus in Germany, 69% were aged 80 or older. Deaths of younger people are probably overreported in the media.
  • Servick, Kelly: Meet the company that has just begun testing a coronavirus vaccine in the United States, Science, 25.03.2020.
  • Boykoff, Jules: Coronavirus postponed the 2020 Tokyo Games. But the Olympic system is still sick., NBC News, 25.03.2020.
  • How we must respond to the COVID-19 pandemic | Bill Gates (TED on YouTube, 52 minutes, 25.03.2020).
  • Klopapier-Knappheit hat Folgen für Kanalisation, SWR aktuell, 25.03.2020.
    Due to the hoarding of toilet paper, people who have run out of toilet paper are resorting to alternatives such as paper towels, wet wipes, which clog up pipes and cause problems in sewage plants.
  • Bericht: Tragische Zustände an Uniklinik Straßburg, SWR aktuell, 25.03.2020.
    Since 21 March, the university hospital in Strasbourg has insufficient ventilators to patients over 80 who have entered a critical state. These patients can only be offered terminal care.
  • Grove, Lloyd; Tani, Maxwell: CNN and MSNBC Staff Push Back on Airing Trump’s Coronavirus ‘Lies’, The Daily Beast, 25.03.2020.
  • Stone, Jon: Coronavirus: Boris Johnson accused of risking lives by refusing to join EU scheme to buy key equipment, The Independent, 25.03.2020.
    Tweeted by Eleanor Rylance, who wrote on 26.03.2020: Instead of joining a huge procurement scheme to buy ventilators from approved manufacturers, Boris Johnson and his government have instead opted to have vacuum cleaner Dyson make them, though they have never made them.
    Think on that. Still feel safe?
  • The Candidates: Postponed after Round 7, ChessBase, 25.03.2020.
  • Levin, Bess: Republicans Are Worried Coronavirus Stimulus Bill Is Too Generous to the Unemployed, Vanity Fair, 25.03.2020.
    Apparently, senators Lindsey Graham, Ben Sasse, Rick Scott and Tim Scott are worried that the legislation will make unemployment so enticing that low-wage workers will decide to lay themselves off. Levin comments, Yes, it takes a real parody of a Republican to worry—at a time when a deadly pandemic is sweeping the nation and doctors are discussing the prospect of having to pick which patients get to live— about the possibility of being too generous to people making 1/1000000th of their annual salary.
    In addition, a G7 statement on the Covid-19 epidemic was delayed because Secretary of State Mike Pompeo insisted on calling the SARS-CoV-2 virus the “Wuhan virus”. Jeff Bezos (the world's richest person) has asked the public to donate to his Amazon Relief Fund to support his company's contract employees.
  • Bernie Sanders Continues to Prove HE'S the Leader We Need Right Now (The Humanist Report on YouTube, 10 minutes, 25.03.2020).
  • Easley, Jonathan: Trump campaign threatens legal action over liberal super PAC ad, The Hill, 25.03.2020.
    An add called ‘Exponential Threat’ has been aired in several states that are crucial to Donald Trump's reelection campaign. The ad combines several quotes from Donald Trump (including one in which he calls the epdemic a hoax) with an animated graph showing the rising number of infections in the USA. Trump's campaign has threatened to sue television stations that broadcast the ad.
    See also the video Trump Threatens To Sue Super PAC For Running Attack Ad Against Him (The Ring of Fire on YouTube, 5 minutes, 26.03.2020).
  • Pramuk, Jacob: Senate passes $2 trillion coronavirus relief bill — House aims for Friday vote, CNBC, 25.03.2020.
    On Twitter, Bay Area for Bernie wrote on 26.03.2020, Today, @SenSanders flexed in the Senate and got $600.00 more PER WEEK in unemployment benefits for FOUR MONTHS on the coronavirus #StimulusBill.
  • Canada backs $75bn coronavirus relief bill, BBC News, 25.03.2020.
    Quote: The bill would give C$2,000 a month for the next four months for people who lost their job because of Covid-19. It would apply to people who are quarantined, helping a sick family member, have been laid off or have not received payment from their employer.
  • Diamond, Dan; Toosi, Nahal: Trump team failed to follow NSC’s pandemic playbook, Politico, 25.03.2020.
    In 2016, the National Security Council (NSC) finished a 69-page document entitled Playbook for Early Response to High-Consequence Emerging Infectious Disease Threats and Biological Incidents. The Trump administration was briefed on the playbook’s existence in 2017, said four former officials, but two cautioned that it never went through a full, National Security Council-led interagency process to be approved as Trump administration strategy. However, an NSC official told Politico that the document was dated and that The plan we are executing now is a better fit, more detailed, and applies the relevant lessons learned from the playbook and the most recent Ebola epidemic in the [Democratic Republic of the Congo] to COVID-19. A health department spokesperson said, The HHS COVID-19 response was informed by more recent plans such as the foundation of the National Biodefense Strategy (2018), Biological Incident Annex (2017), and panCAP (2018) among other key plans provided by the CDC, White House Task Force, FEMA, and other key federal departments and agencies. (It is not clear from the article why these two sources claim that the government's response is working according to a “plan”.)
  • Pinckney, Jonathan; Rivers, Miranda: Nonviolent Action in the Time of Coronavirus, United States Institute of Peace, 25.03.2020.
  • Sanger-Katz, Margot; Abelson, Reed: How to Get Health Insurance if You’re Worried About Coronavirus or Have Lost Your Job, The New York Times, 25.03.2020.
    Dr. Victoria Dooley / @DrDooleyMD tweeted this article on 28 March, adding the comment, What kind of shithole country doesn’t guarantee universal health care as a human right during a pandemic? Asking for a friend.
  • Clifford, Catherine: Bill Gates: If I were president, this is what I would do now to fight coronavirus, CNBC, 25.03.2020, updated 27.03.2020.
    Bill Gates says it is necessary to maintain isolation to flatten the curve. Based on the duration of the isolation in China, the USA should prepare for six weeks of isolation. The president be clear about this, since it is not easy. Gates also emphasizes that it is important to prioritize the toll on human health over money.
  • Anti-Corona-Maßnahmen: Lindner fordert Ausstiegsstrategie, Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung, 25.03.2020.
    FDP president Christian Lindner demanded an exit strategy for the anti-corona measures. He warned against the emergence of an authoritarian state: Wir wollen keinen autoritären Staat, in dem eine Regierung ohne parlamentarische Kontrolle Freiheitseinschränkungen befehlen kann. He also warned against an economy that strongly depends on the state.
    Carsten Linnemann (CDU) demanded that the economic shutdown be lifted after Easter: Für die gesamte Volkswirtschaft und unseren Staat wird der Schaden nachhaltig und über Jahrzehnte nicht kompensierbar sein, wenn wir nicht spätestens nach Ostern die Wirtschaft wieder schrittweise hochfahren.
  • Lerner, Sharon: Gilead Sciences Backs Off Monopoly Claim for Promising Coronavirus Drug, The Intercept, 25.03.2020.
  • Rascoe, Ayesha: Trump Resists Using Wartime Law To Get, Distribute Coronavirus Supplies, NPR, 25.03.2020.
    Quote: Many governors and health officials have been pleading with President Trump to use his authority under the Defense Production Act to get the federal government more directly involved in the buying and distribution of items like ventilators and face masks — items that have been in short supply, with states competing for them.
    "We're a country not based on nationalizing our business," [Trump] said. "Call a person over in Venezuela. Ask them, how did nationalization of their businesses work out? Not too well. The concept of nationalizing our business is not a good concept."
  • Chapman, Matthew: The National Security Council Gave Trump a 69-Page Pandemic Plan Three Years Ago — He Ignored It, New Civil Rights Movement, 25.03.2020.
  • Edwards, Catherine: What's missing from Sweden's coronavirus strategy? Clear communication, The Local, 25.03.2020.
    Sweden is one of the very few countries in Europe where schools and bars are still open. The measures currently in place in Sweden focus on protecting the most vulnerable groups, with over-70s and other members of risk groups urged to stay in their homes as much as possible.
  • 10 stages of COVID QUARANTINE Ft. GANDALF (Impressions Dub) (Charlie Hopkinson on YouTube, 8 minutes, 25.03.2020).
  • De Arteveldehogeschool: lockdown in Gent, De Ideale Wereld on YouTube, 3 minutes, 25.03.2020.
  • Teeta / @anitamassey86 on Twitter, 25.03.2020: This guy has just won the internet.
  • Hoare, Liam: The Coronavirus Could Destroy the EU, Slate, 25.03.2020.

26 March 2020

  • Perspectives on the Pandemic | Dr John Ioannidis of Stanford University | Episode 1 (Journeyman Pictures on YouTube, 62 minutes, 26.03.2020). This interview by John Kirby was recorded at Stanford University on 23 March.
  • McCall, Rosie: New York Hospitals Are Using Vitamin C to Treat Some Coronavirus Patients, Newsweek, 26.03.2020.
    Quotes: The antioxidant is being administered intravenously in quantities far exceeding the daily recommended dose, which is 90 milligrams for men and 75 milligrams for women as recommended by the National Institutes of Health. The effectiveness of intravenous vitamin C as a treatment for—or buffer against—COVID-19 is not established with solid clinical evidence. Rumors spreading online about vitamin C's potential to treat the symptoms of coronavirus, or even prevent them from developing in the first place, have been debunked.
  • Collins, Francis: Genomic Study Points to Natural Origin of COVID-19, NIH Director's blog, 26.03.2020.
  • COVID-19 to send almost all G20 countries into a recession, The Economist, 26.03.2020.

    See Jedd Legum's tweet, 24.03.2020.

  • .@BernieSanders ON FIRE on the Senate floor: "And now I find that some of my Republican colleagues are very distressed they're very upset that somebody is making $10-$12 bucks an hour might end up with a paycheck for four months more than they received last week... (People for Bernie on Twitter, 26.03.2020).
  • Levin, Bess: Of Course the Trump Administration Ignored a Step-by-Step Guide to Fighting a Coronavirus-esque Pandemic, Vanity Fair, 26.03.2020.
  • I've seen this ad made 100 times now. It never gets any less effective. The gaslighting isn't working anymore. Trump's response has been an unmitigated failure, and he owns that. (Brian Tyler Cohen / @briantylercohen on Twitter, 26.03.2020).
    Political host Brian Tyler Cohen posts (or reposts) an ad by Joe Biden's presidential campaign that exposes Donald Trump's failure to properly respond to the crisis. This includes statements by Donald Trump that the epidemic is a new hoax by the Democrats (28 January), that people who are healthy will be fine (29 February), that things are working out (10 March), that he takes no responsibility for the fact that the lag in testing is a failing (13 March), that asking about his disbanding the White House pandemic office is just a nasty question (13 March), that on a scale of 1 to 10, he rates his response to the crisis with a 10 (16 March, by which date, 4466 infections had been reported in the U.S.A.), and that he inherited a broken, obsolete system (22 March).
  • Bedingfield, Will: This is why Germany’s coronavirus death rate seems so low, Wired, 26.03.2020.
  • Coronavirus: Record number of Americans file for unemployment, BBC News, 26.03.2020.
    According to the USA's Department of Labor, Nearly 3.3 million people registered to claim jobless benefits for the week ended 21 March.
  • EPA Announces Enforcement Discretion Policy for COVID-19 Pandemic, Environmental Protection Agency, 26.03.2020.
    Quote: EPA's temporary enforcement discretion policy applies to civil violations during the COVID-19 outbreak. The policy addresses different categories of noncompliance differently. For example, under the policy EPA does not expect to seek penalties for noncompliance with routine monitoring and reporting obligations that are the result of the COVID-19 pandemic but does expect operators of public water systems to continue to ensure the safety of our drinking water supplies. (…) To be eligible for enforcement discretion, the policy also requires facilities to document decisions made to prevent or mitigate noncompliance and demonstrate how the noncompliance was caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. (…) EPA's policy will apply retroactively beginning on March 13, 2020.
  • Beitsch, Rebecca: EPA suspends enforcement of environmental laws amid coronavirus, The Hill, 26.03.2020.
    The Environmental Protection Agency announced that companies would not need to meet environmental regulations for the duration of the Covid-19 pandemic. This temporary policy was not given an end date.
  • Leber, Rebecca: “An Open License to Pollute”: The EPA Has Halted Enforcement Due to COVID-19, Mother Jones, 26.03.2020.
  • Johnson, Jake: 'Holy Crap This Is Insane': Citing Coronavirus Pandemic, EPA Indefinitely Suspends Environmental Rules, Common Dreams, 26.03.2020.
  • Palma, Sky: Christian pastor who thought COVID-19 is just ‘mass hysteria’ among the first in Virginia to die from virus, Raw Story, 26.03.2020.
    “Musical evangelist” Landon Spradlin, who had claimed that the Covid-10 pandemic was the result of “mass hysteria” from the media, who were trying to hurt Donald Trump.
  • Samuels, Brett: Trump questions need for 30,000 ventilators in New York, The Hill, 26.03.2020.
    During a telephone interview during Sean Hannity's show on Fox News, Donald Trump claimed, I don’t believe you need 40,000 or 30,000 ventilators. You know, you go into major hospitals, sometimes they’ll have two ventilators. And now all of a sudden they're saying, 'Can we order 30,000 ventilators?'
  • Tuffrey-Wijne, Irene: Coronavirus and people with intellectual disabilities, Irene Tuffrey-Wijne, 26.03.2020.
  • Nagaraj, Anuradha: Indian ex-slaves unite to inform unaware survivors about coronavirus, Thomson Reuters Foundation, 26.03.2020.
  • Kaufman, Mark: Coronavirus won’t make a dent in the climate problem, Mashable, 26.03.2020.
    Quote: Slowing down the rise in CO2 will mean big, long-term societal changes. If widespread economic shutdowns persist through the coming months, we'll likely see a slowing down of rising CO2 numbers in the atmosphere. But, critically, this won't make a dent in the mass, or pile, of carbon dioxide we've built up over the last 150 years.
  • The next calamity - The coronavirus could devastate poor countries, The Economist, 26.03.2020 (paywalled article).
  • Bücker, Saskia: Ärzte-Appell: Atemschutzmasken in der Öffentlichkeit ausdrücklich erwünscht, Redaktionsnetzwerk Deutschland, 26.03.2020.
  • Henderson, Alex: A Harvard scientist warned the coronavirus could be a ‘thermonuclear pandemic’ — but he was ignored, Alternet, 26.03.2020.
    Harvard-associated epidemiologist Eric-Feigl Ding already warned about the pandemic in January: On January 20 — two months ago — Feigl-Ding posted an in-depth Twitter thread warning how deadly a global COVID-19 pandemic could become. And the things that Wallace-Wells warned about in his thread have come to pass.
  • Wallace-Wells, David: Why Was It So Hard to Raise the Alarm on the Coronavirus?, Intelligencer, 26.03.2020.
    This is another article about the warning Eric-Feigl Ding posted on Twitter. The thread has since been deleted, though you can still read a preserved version of it here.

27 March 2020

  • Cheng, Ching-Tse: WHO chief blames Taiwan for soiled reputation amid coronavirus failings, Taiwan News, 27.03.2020.
    Quote: As a petition calling for the resignation of World Health Organization (WHO) Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus surpasses 580,000 signatures, the Ethiopian health official is reported to have accused Taiwanese netizens of most of the online criticism leveled against him.
  • Strong, Matthew: Chinese media question official coronavirus death tally for Wuhan, Taiwan News, 27.03.2020.
    Quote: Chinese media have begun questioning the official coronavirus death tally in the city of Wuhan as a local mortuary prepared double the number of urns for cremated victims, reports said Friday (March 27).
  • Coronavirus: US overtakes China with most cases, BBC News, 27.03.2020.
    The USA now has more than 86,000 confirmed cases of coronavirus, whereas China has 81,897 cases and Italy 80,589. In the USA, 1,300 people have died of Covid-19, compared to 3,296 in China and 8,215 in Italy. These figures were provided by Johns Hopkins University. Donald Trump's plan to reopen the country on 12 April (Easter Sunday) faced a lot of criticism as it emerged an unprecedented 3.3 million Americans have been laid off because of the virus.
    Bruce Lawson (27.03.2020) quoted an earlier statement by Trump: "I like this stuff. I really get it… every one of these doctors said, ‘how do you know so much about this?’ Maybe I have a natural ability."
    Tomas Pueyo / @tomaspueyo (27.03.2020) wrote, The US just became the country with most #coronavirus cases in the world. Given the current trend and measures, it will likely keep that title forever. It is now likely it will have at least hundreds of thousands of cases, and tens of thousands of deaths.
  • Reich, Robert: So let me get this straight: the Trump administration is willing to hand out $500B to corporations to save executives, but isn't willing to spend $1 billion on more ventilators to save the American people? (Twitter, 27.03.2020).
  • Cohen, Rachel M.: To Develop a Covid-19 Vaccine, Pharma and the Federal Government Will Have to Break Old Patterns, The Intercept, 27.03.2020.
  • Hou, Chia-Yi: The smartest people to follow about coronavirus and what they're saying now, The Hill, 27.03.2020.
  • Wallace, Paul: The virus and the euro, Prospect, 27.03.2020.
  • Lemaire, Martin: DIRECT. Coronavirus en France : 300 morts et 3809 cas ce vendredi, un week-end catastrophe annoncé linternaute, 27.03.2020.
  • Behr, Rafael: The UK is showing enormous trust in the resilience of its democratic culture. Is it right to? Prospect, 27.03.2020.
  • Stallmach, Lena: Warum auch junge Menschen schwer an Covid-19 erkranken, Neue Zürcher Zeitung, 27.03.2020 (paywalled article).
  • Fang, Lee: Debt Collection Industry Deems Itself Essential to “Financial Health” of Consumers, Fights Covid-19 Shutdown, The Intercept, 27.03.2020.
    Tweeted by Ryan Grim on 27.03.2020 saying, Newest outrage from @lhfang : Lobbyists for debt collectors are fighting for the right to continue collecting during the pandemic, arguing it's for the good of consumers and their "ethnically diverse" workforce.
  • Collette, Matt: How the Rich and Powerful Profit From Crises Like Coronavirus, ProPublic, 27.03.2020 (podcast).
  • Kormann, Carolyn: From Bats to Human Lungs, the Evolution of a Coronavirus, The New Yorker, 27.03.2020.
  • Chansky, Tamar: Keep School, Cancel Grades: It’s What You Do in a Pandemic, Psychology Today, 27.03.2020.
    Parents already worried about their children before the pandemic, and many chldren already had anxiety-related disorders.
    Quote: Our children are beyond stressed just trying to learn how to work Zoom or Google classroom. On top of that, they are worrying about their assignments, tests, and grades, just as they always did, but now from an emotionally shaky starting point where everything is turned upside down. The author, who is a therapist, offers the following advice: It’s time to step out of the normal, look at the big picture and what’s at stake, and take the pressure off our kids by cancelling grades in this pandemic semester.
  • Judd, Ron: ER doctor who criticized Bellingham hospital’s coronavirus protections has been fired, Seattle Times, 27.03.2020.
    Dr. Ming Lin, who publicly decried what he called a lack of protective measures against the novel coronavirus at his workplace, PeaceHealth St. Joseph Medical Center, has been fired.
  • Fritze, John: Trump administration faces pushback for coronavirus postcard prominently displaying president's name, USA Today, 27.03.2020.
    A postcard entitled “President Trump's coronavirus guidelines for America” and that was sent to 130 million households, features Trump's name more prominently than the social distancing guidelines that public health officials recommend. Critics say that Trump uses the CDC and the post office to increase his chances of re-election.
  • Coronavirus: Aantal sterfgevallen in Spanje versnelt opnieuw - '100.000 tot 200.000 doden mogelijk in VS', Knack, 27.03.2020.
  • Bleibende Schäden wahrscheinlich: Wie Covid-19 die Lunge angreift, n-tv.de, 27.03.2020.
  • Kuhn, Johannes: Corona-App – Die Freiheit zur Selbstüberwachung, Deutschlandfunk Kultur, 27.03.2020.
    Health minister Jens Spahn is thinking about ways to track people who have been infected with Covid-19, either by analysing cell phone data or through the voluntary use of a tracking app. The latter solution looks more attractive than the former. Since we already let companies such as Google and Facebook track what we do, this type of app would not cause much extra harm to our privacy. However, the voluntary app-based tracking would only work if almost everybody uses the app, which is unrealistic in a population the size of Germany's.
  • Stieber, Benno: Datenschutzbeauftragter empört: „Da werden Dämme eingerissen“, taz, 27.03.2020.
    Tweeted by CCC Updates on 28.03.2020: Rechtswidrige Weitergabe von Patientendaten durch Gesundheitsämter in BaWü, auch von Patienten-Angehörigen, an Polizeibeamte: „Das führt völlig in die falsche Richtung“
  • Say, Mark: King’s College London launches coronavirus symptoms app, UKAuthority, 27.03.2020.
    Quote: King’s College London has developed a smartphone app to track symptoms related to coronavirus and allow users to self-report daily as part of a research programme.
  • Hern, Alex: Trolls exploit Zoom privacy settings as app gains popularity, The Guardian, 27.03.2020.
    Zoom's video conferencing tool has become very popular since the beginning of the Covid-19 pandemic. However, its default settings are based on the assumption that conference participants can trust each other. Some so-called zoombombers have used it to broadcast objectionable content (in publicly accessible teleconferences), others have used it filesharing function to spread malware.
  • Dr. Zinn gibt Tipps: So kann man Covid-19 selbst behandeln, n-tv.de, 27.03.2020.
    Dr. Zinn recommends the usual householf remedies that people use for colds: rest, sufficient hydration, healthy nutrition, possibly antipyretics (i.e fever-reducing tablets). However, when coughing and fever increase, people should contact a a doctor or a hospital.
  • Rusnell, Charles: Alberta health minister accused of berating Calgary physician, 'intimidating' citizens, CBC, 27.03.2020.
  • Driessen, Barbara: Ausländische Fachkräfte für deutsche Krankenhäuser unentbehrlich, MiGAZIN, 27.03.2020.
  • Bruhns, Annette; Thim, Katja; Weinzierl, Alfred: Zwischen Überforderung und gespenstischer Stille, Der Spiegel, 27.03.2020.
  • COVID-19, une leçon de géopolitique #01- Les deux Corée face au virus (Le Dessous des cartes — ARTE on YouTube, 9 minutes, 27.03.2020).
  • Greenstone, Michael; Nigam, Vishan: Does Social Distancing Matter?, University of Chicago, Becker Friedman Institute for Economics Working Paper No. 2020-26, SSRN, 27.03.2020, updated 31.03.2020.
    See also Does Social Distancing Matter? on the BFI website (25.03.2020).
  • Chávez, Aída: Millions of People Will Struggle to Pay Rent in April, but Few in Congress Care, The Intercept, 27.03.2020.
    On Friday 26 March, the House of Representatives passed a bill for a relief package that is about five times bigger than Barack Obama’s 2009 stimulus. Though it includes a significant expansion of unemployment benefits and a onetime check of up to $1,200 for individuals and $2,400 for couples, it’ll take up to three weeks for people to begin receiving those relief checks, according to Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin. That will be too late for the nearly 3.3 million people who filed for unemployment benefits last week, and others who have become underemployed as a result of the pandemic.
  • Bill Gates makes a prediction about when coronavirus cases will peak (CNN on YouTube, 11 minutes, 27.03.2020).
  • Handyortung: Snowden warnt vor Überwachung über Corona-Pandemie hinaus, Redaktionsnetzwerk Deutschland, 27.03.2020.
  • Stacks of urns in China's Wuhan prompt new questions of coronavirus toll, Sraits Times, 27.03.2020.
    Quotes: Outside one funeral home, trucks shipped in about 2,500 urns on both Wednesday (March 25) and Thursday, according to Chinese media outlet Caixin. Another picture published by Caixin showed 3,500 urns stacked on the ground inside. It's unclear how many of the urns had been filled.
    (…) According to Chinese government figures, 2,535 people in Wuhan have died of the virus.     There were 56,007 cremations in Wuhan in the fourth quarter of 2019, according to data from the city's civil affairs agency. The number of cremations was 1,583 higher than those in the fourth quarter of 2018 and 2,231 higher than the fourth quarter of 2017.
  • Laurent, Lionel: Want to Escape a Lockdown? Try Sweden, Bloomberg, 27.03.2020.
  • lavventura: Le coronavirus tue le couple: comment s’immuniser, Le Monde blog, 27.03.2020.
  • Gombeaud, Adrien: 7 grands écrivains inspirés par les épidémies, Les Echos, 27.03.2020.
    La Peste (Albert Camus), Le Fléau (Stephen King), L'Année du lion (Deon Meyer), Les Animaux malades de la peste (Jean de La Fontaine), Le Hussard sur le toit (Jean Giono), Journal de l'année de la peste (Daniel Defoe), Le Masque de la mort rouge (Edgar Allan Poe).

28 March 2020

  • WHO-Anleitung: So können Sie Desinfektionsmittel selbst machen, Redaktionsnetzwerk Deutschland, 28.03.2020.
    Quote: Das Rezept der WHO war ursprünglich für Drittweltländer als preiswerte Alternative zu fertigen Desinfektionsmitteln entwickelt worden. Im Zuge des Coronavirus-Ausbruchs könnte es aber auch hierzulande hilfreich sein, ein eigenes Mittel herzustellen.
  • Treviranus, Jutta: It’s Time to Drop “Darwinism” and Listen to Darwin and His Successors on Human Evolution, Medium, 28.03.2020 (Creative Commons).
    When politicians such as Donald Trump and Boris Johnson suggest that it is acceptable to sacrifice the elderly for the sake of the economy or herd immunity, they are invoking social darwinism. However, the theory of evolution has changed significantly since Darwin, and social darwinism was debunked in the early twentieth century. One thing we have learnt is that diversity and variation, as opposed to being the strongest or closer to the average, are essential to survival of our species. In addition “fittest” does not refer to strength but to the ability to adapt. From the point of view of the survival of a collective species, we need to take a long-term systemic view. Several authors have already made the valid argument that the polluters and exploitative robber barons threaten the human race and are of less (if not negative) value to the survival of the species. However, there are other points to consider: Most humans understand the value of investing in our future by protecting the defenseless young. Many cultures understand the importance of preserving the wisdom and knowledge provided only through a long lifetime of experience, by our old.
    If we respect and include others who are fragile, we are compelled to create a more generous and kinder society, a society that will treat us kindly when we are at our weakest, when we are struggling. (…)
  • Mackey, Robert: In Exchange for Aid, Trump Wants Praise From Governors He Can Use in Campaign Ads, The Intercept, 28.03.2020.
    Governor Jay Inslee of Washington and governor Gretchen Whitmer of Michigan, both Democrats, had criticised Trump: Whitmer had said that the federal government had not taken the epidemic seriously early enough, whereas Inslee had rebuked Trump for leaving the states to fend for themselves. Trump still thought that his government has done a hell of a job and complained that the governors are not appreciative to him. Trump contrasted these two Democratic governors with two Republican governors, Andrew Cuomo of New York and Gavin Newsom of California, who had expressed appreciation. (…)
    On 27 March, Governor Gretchen Whitmer / @GoveWhitmer tweeted, Hi, my name is Gretchen Whitmer, and that governor is me 👋
    I've asked repeatedly and respectfully for help. We need it. No more political attacks, just PPEs, ventilators, N95 masks, test kits. You said you stand with Michigan — prove it.
    (…) An update to the article adds that governor Whitmer, had spoken with Vice President Mike Pence and thanked the White House for declaring a major disaster declaration for Michigan, freeing up federal assistance for the state, two days after it was requested. She also thanked the FEMA for a new shipment of 112,000 N95 masks to her state’s emergency operations center.
  • Richie Holland on Twitter, 28.03.2020: Reporter: Can everyone who needs a ventilator get one?
    Trump: “Look, don’t be a cutie-pie, okay?”
  • Alba, Davey; Frenkel, Sheera: A Single Gesture Behind Trump Fuels an Online Conspiracy Theory, The New York Times, 28.03.2020.
    The gesture in question is what Dr. Fauci did during a White House briefing: At a White House briefing on the coronavirus on March 20, President Trump called the State Department the “Deep State Department.” Behind him, Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, the director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, dropped his head and rubbed his forehead.
    Open Culture / @openculture tweeted this article on 28 March, commenting, Dr. Anthony Fauci has become the target of claims that he is mobilizing to undermine the president.
    #dumbanddumber
  • Truscott, Lucian K. IV: For Trump, there’s only one victim: himself. He fears political defeat more than the deaths of millions, Raw Story, 28.03.2020.

    Ein Virologe und ein Ökonom diskutieren über die Corona-Pandemie: «Die Politiker behaupten nun, Deutschland habe superschnell reagiert, aber das stimmt einfach nicht» (Paywall / requires registration.)
  • Corona und der Datenschutz – Helfen Bewegungsprofile gegen das Virus? Deutschlandfunk Kultur, 28.03.2020.
    Hong Kong tracks newly arrived people using a digital bracelet; Singapore uses the community-based app TraceTogether; in China, WeChat and Alibaba installed extensions to track infected individuals; South Korea developed an app for the surveillance of quarantined individuals. However, Eva Blum-Dumontet of Privacy International claims that anonymised data hardly still exist; the identification of individuals requires very few data. Measures that endanger people's privacy require a legal basis and a well-informed public. It is also important to look at what companies are entrusted with this task and what will happen with the collected data after the Covid-19 pandemic. (…)
  • Wall Street Journal reporter Rebecca Ballhaus on Twitter, 28.03.2020 Trump has told people he wants his signature to appear on the direct payment checks that will go out to many Americans. Normally, a civil servant—the disbursing officer for the payment center—would sign federal checks.
    @AndrewRestuccia scoop:
    Siobhan Hughes & Natalie Andrews: Trump Signs $2 Trillion Coronavirus Stimulus Bill After Swift Passage by House, The Wall Street Journal, 27.03.2020 (paywalled article).
  • Evan McMullin on Twitter, 28.03.2020: Trump admitted that he instructs his team not to help, or to help less, states with governors who criticize his dangerously inept response to this pandemic. In his sick, sociopathic mind, his ego is more important than literally thousands of American lives.
  • Bitkom-Chef: Datenschutz muss hinter Schutz von Leben zurückstehen, heise.de, 28.03.2020.
    Achim Berg, president of Bitkom, is in favour of subordinating our concers about privacy to the use of apps that help in the fight against the Covid-19 epidemic. (The Austrian Red Cross has already developed a Stopp-Corona-App and claims that users don't need to reveal any personal data.)
  • Pilkington, Ed; McCarthy, Tom: The missing six weeks: how Trump failed the biggest test of his life, The Guardian, 28.03.2020.
  • Biller, David: Brazil’s Bolsonaro makes life-or-death coronavirus gamble, AP News, 28.03.2020.
  • Trump PANICS, Tries to Scrub "Coronavirus Hoax" Clips (David Pakman Show on YouTube, 8 minutes, 28.03.2020).
    This is about Trump trying to suppress evidence that he called the pandemic a hoax — in order to protect his re-election campaign. The ad is called Exponential Threat and was posted on YouTube on 23 March 2020.
  • van den Brink, Rinke: Honderdduizenden Chinese mondmaskers teruggeroepen uit Nederlandse ziekenhuizen, NOS, 28.03.2020.
    600,000 FP2 masks from a batch of 1.3 million masks imported from China were taken out of hospitals again after some hospitals had had some of them tested by TNO and found that they did not even conform to the criteria for FFP1.
  • After Spain and Czech Republic, now Turkey discards faulty Chinese Coronavirus testing kits over inaccurate results, OpIndia, 28.03.2020.

29 March 2020

  • Zhao, Christina: Wuhan COVID-19 Death Toll May Be in Tens of Thousands, Data on Cremations and Shipments of Urns Suggest, Newsweek, 29.03.2020.
  • Japan vice PM hits out at WHO for excluding Taiwan (民視英語新聞 Formosa TV English News on YouTube, 2 minutes, 29.03.2020).
  • “Mehr Ansteckungen zulassen”: Infektiologe spricht sich für Herdenimmunität aus, Redaktionsnetzwerk Deutschland, 29.03.2020.
    Infectologist Ansgar Lohse of the univerisity hospital Hamburg-Eppendorf recommends allowing more Covid-19 infections among people who are least at risk of developing serious conditions in order to increase herd immunity in the population. He is concerned that the measures taken by the German government may have serious consequences. The social distancing and isolation increase violence within families. In addition, an economic recession can also cost lives. Since he does not expect a vaccine to become available before 2021, he recommends a controlled spread of Covid-19 among children and young parents in order to increase immunity in these age groups. However, this also requires better protection of groups who are at risk of developing serious conditions.
  • Kippt das Virus bald die ersten Staatspräsidenten?, Redaktionsnetzwerk Deutschland, 29.03.2020.
    Alexander Lukashenko, President of Belarus since 1994, still considers the Covid-19 pandemic as a psychosis. He even claimed that there are no viruses, since he had never seen any. Similarly, Jair Bolsonaro and Andrés Manuel López Obrador, presidents of Brasil and Mexico, respectively, are not taking the pandemic seriously either.
  • Seuchenhistoriker im Interview: "Das ist ein gigantisches Experiment", n-tv.de, 29.03.2020.
    According to historian Karl-Heinz Leven, who has been studying epidemics, had not expected a pandemic with the impact of the current Covid19 pandemic. There is no historical precedent for a situation in which millions of people stay at home and entire national economies have been shut down. What Leven is most concerned about is not the death toll but an economic collapse caused by the isolation measures.
    That China lifted the lockdown in Wuhan and claims that there are no new infections looks like a medical miracle. Leven wonders whether the Chinese authorities are now letting the epidemic spread through the country to save the economy. He recommends sobriety and rationality in dealing with the epidemic. Chancellor Merkel appears to be doing a good job in this regard.
  • Epidemiologe alarmiert: Kontaktsperre und Co gefährlicher als Corona? ZDF, 29.03.2020.
    Epidemiologist Gérard Krause warns about the economic and social consequences of the current measures to halt the spread of the Covid-19 epidemic. For example, unemployment increases the risk of disease and even death. Limiting the freedom of movement probably also has a negative impact on people's health. Germany may be able to absorb the shock relatively well, but this is not the case for many other countries, for example, in Africa and South America. We should be aware of potential negative consequences since these may be bigger than we currently assume and may become apparent with a certain delay. (…)
  • Edwards, David: Steve Mnuchin insists Americans can live on just $17/day during pandemic, Raw Story, 29.03.2020.
    Quote: Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin on Sunday said that he expects Americans to be able to survive for two and a half months on just $1,200, which is about $17 per day.
  • Sabine Rennefanz, Twitter, 29.03.2020: Kein Karneval, weniger bis kaum Ski-Urlaub in Tirol und Italien, weniger reiche und mobile Vielreisende, dünner besiedelt. Meine Vermutungen. (No carnival, fewer people who went skiing in Tirol or Italy, fewer rich and mobile frequent travelers, more sparsely populated. My conjectures.) In response to a tweet by Olaf Gersemann who wondered why there were significantly fewer Covid-19 infections in the former DDR.
  • Report: Fox News is worried about legal action after misleading viewers about coronavirus, Media Matters for America, 29.03.2020.
  • Jay Rosen on Twitter, 29.03.2020: "...I've been talking to Fox insiders over the last few days, there's a real concern inside the network that their early downplaying of the coronavirus actually exposes Fox News to potential legal action by viewers who maybe were misled. " —@gabrielsherman
  • Kneipen und Kitas bleiben offen: Schweden geht den Corona-Sonderweg, n-tv.de, 29.03.2020.
  • Landesregierung veröffentlicht Bußgeldkatalog: Das kostet der Verstoß gegen die Corona-Maßnahmen in Baden-Württemberg, SWR Aktuell, 29.03.2020.
  • Corona-Kontaktverbot: Polizei verstärkt Kontrollen in Rhein-Neckar-Region, SWR Aktuell, 29.03.2020.

  • van Wagtendonk, Anya: The government is distributing emergency Covid-19 supplies. But some states are losing out., Vox, 29.03.2020.
    An article in The Washington Post suggests, anecdotally, that federal allocation of medical resources do not seem to target density of need, but rather the political makeup of affected communities.
  • La Chine a-t-elle minimisé son nombre de morts du coronavirus ? Europe 1, 29.03.2020.
    Quote: Selon le professeur émérite de microbiologie et ancien directeur de l'institut Pasteur de Lille Patrick Berche, il est peu probable que la Chine ait eu si peu de morts, moins de 5.000 quand des pays comme l'Italie comptent plus de 10.000 victimes du coronavirus.
  • You Can Thank Government Bashing Republicans For Pandemic (The Ring of Fire on YouTube, 4 minutes, 29.03.2020).
  • Dr Michelle Dickinson / @medickinson on Twitter, 29.03.2020: New Zealand early lockdown has to be one of the best in the world. Was just looking for flights & found 1 cargo plane. Then thought I’d look at what the plane travel situation looked like for the country with the highest number of confirmed #COVID-19 cases in the world the USA Flushed face The tweet contains two images from Planefinder: one for flights in New Zealand (only one flight) and one for flights in the USA (so many, probably hundreds, that they can't be easily counted).

30 March 2020

  • Cohen, Arianne: COVID-19 tracking map shows multiple strains of coronavirus spreading across the world, Fast Company, 30.03.2020.
    Quote: COVID-19 is mutating slowly, with eight current strains, making a long-lasting vaccine more feasible.
  • Die gesamtwirtschaftliche Lage angesichts der Corona-Pandemie, Sachverständigenrat Wirtschaft, 30.03.2020.
  • Wirtschaftsweise fürchten Einbruch um bis zu 5,4 Prozent, Welt, 30.03.2020.
  • Rath, Christian: Maskenpflicht in der Öffentlichkeit: Länder könnten Mundschutz anordnen, taz, 30.03.2020.
  • Coronavirus live: Kurz ordnet Masken-Pflicht im Supermarkt an, WELT, 30.03.2020.
    The Austrian chancellor Sebastian Kurz decreed the obligatory wearing of protective masks in supermarkets. Such masks do not provide full protection against infections but they can reduce infections through the air. The masks will be distributed in supermarkets.
  • Österreich beschließt Mundschutz-Pflicht in Supermärkten, t-online.de, 30.03.2020.
  • Debatte in Deutschland: Mundschutzpflicht vorerst kein Thema, tagesschau.de, 30.03.2020.
    After Austria made wearing masks mandatory in supermarkets, some German politicians also appear to be in favour of such a measure in Germany. The WHO, however, said that requiring the general public to wear face masks is not useful. Instead, it could lead to new risks, when people take off the mask incorrectly and thereby infect themselves.
  • Müller, Moritz: Britische Justiz scheint Assanges Immunsystem testen zu wollen, Nachdenkseiten, 30.03.2020.
  • Chotiner, Isaac: The Contrarian Coronavirus Theory That Informed the Trump Administration, The New Yorker, 30.03.2020.
  • Steinfeld, Jemimah: We must make sure UK coronavirus legislation is only temporary, Index on Censorship, 30.03.2020.
    The UK's Coronavirus Bill gives the government a lot of power. For example, it allows authorities to isolate or detain individuals who are judged to be a risk to containing the spread of Covid-19. The bill does not include an originally proposed “sunset date” of two years but a clause stating the legislation will be reviewed every six months. Steinfeld thinks the Corona Bill passes John Stuart Mill's liberty test (the only purpose for which power can be rightfully exercised over any member of a civilized community, against his will, is to prevent harm to others); it is causing harm to many people.
  • Erick Fernandez / @ErickFernandez on Twitter, 30.03.2020: Accusing nurses and doctors of stealing protective gear during a pandemic as they’re trying to save lives would ruin the chance of a re-election in a normal world. Trump had implied that healthcare workers in New York were stealing masks.

    48 hours later, Trump tweeted, Upon information and belief, Iran or its proxies are planning a sneak attack on U.S. troops and/or assets in Iraq. If this happens, Iran will pay a very heavy price, indeed!
  • Rupar, Aaron: Trump says 200,000 Americans could die from coronavirus, because he’s done “a very good job”, Vox, 30.03.2020.
    Quote: “You’re talking about 2.2 million deaths,” Trump said, referring to an Imperial College study that identified 2.2 million people as the high end of how many Americans could die if no measures were taken to slow the spread of coronavirus. “So if we can hold that down, as we’re saying, to 100,000, it’s a horrible number, maybe even less, but to 100,000, so we have between 100 [thousand] and 200,000, we altogether have done a very good job.”
  • Heasley, Shaun: Trump Administration Says Disability No Reason To Deny COVID-19 Care, Disability Scoop, 30.03.2020.
    Quote: In a bulletin issued Saturday, the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services’ Office for Civil Rights said that the Americans with Disabilities Act, Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act and other laws prohibiting discrimination in federally-funded health programs remain in effect.
  • Resnick, Brian: Social distancing can’t last forever. Here’s what should come next., Vox, 30.03.2020.
  • Tollefson, Jeff: Climate vs coronavirus: Why massive stimulus plans could represent missed opportunities, Nature, 30.03.2020.
    The US$2-trillion economic-stimulus plan passed by US Congress on 27 March is a setback for environmentalists. The measures that many countries have taken are already leading to a reduction in air pollution, for example in China and Italy. The pandemic may also trigger an economic crisis that will reduce energy demands, but whether there will be lasting effects on emissions will depend on what the economic-stimulus plans will look like. Glen Peters, research director at the Center for International Climate Research in Oslo: It is not as if building solar panels is going to put the tourism or restaurant industry back to work.
    Barack Obama's stimulus package after the 2008 financial crisis included investments in green infrastructure and in research and development into renewable energy. However, there is a danger that governments may fall back on high-carbon projects because that is easier.
  • Hallegatte, Stéphane; Hammer, Stephen: Thinking ahead: For a sustainable recovery from COVID-19, World Bank Blogs, 30.03.2020.
  • Greenwood, Faine: Google Wants Your Data in Exchange for a Coronavirus Test, Foreign Policy, 30.03.2020.
    Google's sister company Verily has developed a Coronavirus test but users must have a Google account to use it.
  • Meyer, Robinson: Exclusive: Kushner Firm Built the Coronavirus Website Trump Promised, The Atlantic, 30.03.2020.
  • Shaun Rein, Founder of CMR / @shaunrein, on Twitter, 30.03.2020: My gosh. The rumors. The disinformation. No, the Chinese govt isn't hiding 20 million deaths from coronavirus
    Mobile phone subscriptions dropped because migrant workers often use 2 #s. They cut 1 as they stayed at home, used wifi, unsure when return work     (This is a comment on a Bloomberg article from 23 March: China’s Mobile Carriers Lose 21 Million Users as Virus Bites.)
  • Ruttenberg, Danya: Most Will Survive This Pandemic. But Now is the Prudent Time to Settle Your Affairs | Opinion, Newsweek, 30.03.2020.
    The author says it is time for us all to do the painful but necessary work of preparing for the possibility of our own worst case scenarios coming to pass. She proposes a short to-do list. First, one should write down what you want to happen in the event that you are unable to make medical decisions for yourself. Second, it is important to write your will if you don't have one yet. Finally, one should make these important documents accessible to loved ones.
  • Hamilton, Isobel Asher: Amazon warehouse workers in New York will strike after an employee tested positive for coronavirus, Business Insider, 30.03.2020.
  • Mak, Aaron: Amazon and Instacart Workers Are Striking for COVID-19 Protections, Slate, 30.03.2020.
    Quote: Like Instacart, Amazon is seeing a surge of orders similar to what it would see on Prime Day or Black Friday, spurring the company to open 100,000 new full- and part-time positions in the U.S. to help keep up with demand and offer $2 per hour raises through April. But Amazon warehouse workers say they’re not being protected as the virus spreads.
  • Gordts, Pieter; Galle, Cathy: Naar 10.000 tests per dag: vanaf volgende week kan ons land veel meer testen, De Morgen, 30.03.2020.

31 March 2020

  • Stich, Simon: Selbstgebastelte Maske: Wissenschaftler enthüllen das beste Material (Update), GIGA, 31.03.2020.
    This article looks at what household materials would be most efficacious for homemade masks, based on the academic paper Testing the Efficacy of Homemade Masks: Would They Protect in an Influenza Pandemic? from 2013.
  • Ferretti, Luca; Wymant, Chris; Kendall, Michelle; Zhao, Lele; Nurtay, Anel; Abeler-Dörner, Lucie; Parker, Michael; Bonsall, David; Fraser, Christophe: Quantifying SARS-CoV-2 transmission suggests epidemic control with digital contact tracing, Science, 31.03.2020.
  • Audureau, William: L’étrange obsession d’un quart des Français pour la thèse du virus créé en laboratoire, Le Monde, 31.03.2020.
    According to an IFOP poll published on 28 March, 26% of French citizens believe that the SARS-CoV-2 virus was created in a laboratory.
  • Jena erlässt Mundschutz-Pflicht: Nur mit Schutzmaske in den Supermarkt, ZDF, 31.03.2020.
  • Hochschulen rechnen mit "digitalem Semester", SWR aktuell, 31.03.2020.
  • RKI-Chef zu Problembewusstsein: Wieler: Langsam nehmen die Deutschen Covid-19 ernst, n-tv.de, 31.03.2020.
  • Bauer gegen "Nicht-Semester" an Hochschulen, SWR aktuell, 31.03.2020.
    Theresia Bauer, minister of science and education in Baden-Württemberg, is against a &dquo;zero semester”. She said, Wir wollen, dass unsere Hochschulen so weit wie möglich auf Online-Formate umstellen und neue Wege beschreiten für den Studienbetrieb. (We want that higher education institutions switch over to digital formats as much as possible and that they find new ways to continue education.)
  • Bürger sollen Verstöße gegen Kontaktsperre melden, SWR aktuell, 31.03.2020.
    Thomas Strobl (CDU), interior minister of Baden-Württemberg, encourages citizens to report violations against the measures to limit contact between people: Ich bin dankbar, wenn die Bürger und Bürgerinnen wachsam sind und uns helfen.
    See also the Twitter poll by Boris Reitschuster / @reitschuster, 31.03.2020:
    BWs Innenminister Strobl (CDU) hat dazu aufgerufen, Verstöße gegen die Anti-Coronamaßnahmen der Polizei zu melden. #Corona stellt uns vor massive Dilemmas. Nach den massiven Demokratie- und Freiheits-Beschneidungen nun auch der Aufruf zum Denunzieren - wie sehen Sie das?
    • Richtig in dieser Krise
    • Geht trotz allem zu weit
    • Bin ich überfragt
  • Lerner, Sharon: EPA Is Jamming Through Rollbacks That Could Increase Coronavirus Deaths, The Intercept, 31.03.2020.
    In addition to lifting requirements on the enforcement of pullution laws, the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) is also planning to limit the use of research based on private health data. People who have developed breathing problems due to the effects of air pollution are more vulnerable to the Corona virus. EPA data support the connection between the pollution by refineries and breahing problems. (…)
  • Trump Supporters Are Breaking Quarantine To "Trigger The Libs" (The Ring of Fire on YouTube, 4 minutes, 31.03.2020).
  • Linton, Megan: ‘We Have Always Been Disposable’: the Structural Violence of Neoliberal Healthcare, Canadian Dimension, 31.03.2020.
    Quote: The marriage of neoliberalism and the medical industrial complex has had disastrous results in Canada, even without the presence of a pandemic. This toxic relationship has led to decades of healthcare cuts, privatization of services, and warehousing of disabled and elder populations. Now, COVID-19 is exacerbating an already broken system.
  • Yonhap: S. Korea to begin new school year with online classes, The Korea Herald, 31.03.2020.
    The start of the new school year had been delayed to give schools more time to prepare for online teaching. For middle and high school senior students , the school year will start on 9 April, on 16 April for irst and second graders at middle and high schools, and elementary school students in the fourth to sixth grades, and on 20 April for first to third graders at elementary schools.
  • Ock, Hyun-ju: Virus forces schools to go virtual, but many are still unprepared, The Korea Herald, 31.03.2020.
    Since many families don't have access to technology needed for online learning, the government will provide students from low-income families with smart devices and internet connections. Out of some 290,000 students from households considered as earning low income, 170,000 students were without smart devices, according to a survey on 67 percent of the schools nationwide by the ministry.
  • Kim, Bo-gyun: Seoul gives masks free to foreigners alienated in public rationing, The Korea Herald, 31.03.2020.
  • Schutzausrüstung, Corona-Verordnung und Co.: Livestream der BW-Regierungspressekonferenz zur Corona-Lage, SWR Aktuell, 31.03.2020.
    Includes the following: 30 Millionen Atemschutzmasken mit Hilfe von Porsche aus China.
  • How to Prepare for the Trump Recession with Robert Reich (Robert Reich on YouTube, 4 minutes, 31.03.2020).
    Reich says that the USA can do three things to prepare:
    1. reform unemployment insurance so it reflects the needs of today's economy,
    2. strengthen Temporary Assistance for Needy Families,
    3. protect the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) (also known as food stamps).
  • Collins, Sean: Leaked audio suggests Trump is in denial about the coronavirus testing problem, Vox, 31.03.2020.
    The USA has ramped up Covid-19 testing; as of Saturday 28 March, 894,000 tests had been done. However, according to an article in The Washington Post, 2,250 tests per million people is roughly two-thirds of the testing rate South Korean reached three weeks earlier.
  • Stout, Matt: Warren to feds: Why did you take Massachusetts’ medical supplies?, Boston Globe, 31.03.2020.
    Elizabeth Warren tweeted on 31.03.2020: Trump told states they were on their own to purchase medical equipment, so that’s what MA tried to do. But then the federal government outbid MA at least 3 times – and reports show two of our orders were seized by federal authorities. This is unacceptable. The second tweet in the same thread says, MA requested supplies from the Strategic National Stockpile nearly a month ago. Only a fraction ever came. Without Trump’s full & consistent use of the DPA, state officials are still scrambling to find essential equipment but the federal govt has created a logistical black hole. And the third tweet, Health care providers & public health leaders in MA & across the country are doing everything they can to fight this crisis, but the Trump administration continues to fail them. I want @FEMA to explain how the federal govt will make sure states like MA receive their supplies.
  • 'It's like being on eBay': US states competing to buy ventilators, says Cuomo (Guardian News on YouTube, 2 minutes, 31.03.2020).
    Governor Cuomo explains that in order to buy ventilators and other equipment, the State of New York effectively needs to compete with fifty other states who are bidding for the same supplies. Then FEMA also starts bidding, thereby driving up the price for the states. FEMA should have been the purchasing agent buying the supplies and then allocating it to the states based on need.
  • À Wuhan, les funérariums pris d'assaut sèment le doute sur le nombre de victimes du coronavirus, France 24, 31.03.2020.
    In Wuhan, China, the high number of cremations raises questions about the real number of deaths caused by Covid-19. A cremation in Hankow in Wuhan had been working 19 hours per day during the 29 days of February, totalling 16.530 cremations for the entire month. However, Chinese authorities had claimed that 2.535 persons had died of Covid-19 in Wuhan.
  • NYC emergency room doctor on battling coronavirus, MSNBC, 31.03.2020. (Description: NYC Emergency Room Doctor Calvin Sun talks with Katy Tur about his first handing experience on the frontlines of Coronavirus.)
    Katy Tur on Twitter, 31.03.2020: He’s worked 18 shifts in the last 21 days, intubated his own nursing staff, and seen ER patients - clearly COVID positive - wait for 80 hours for a bed upstairs.
    Harrowing tales from inside NYC ERs.
  • Herr, Orna: How coronavirus is affecting free speech in Europe, Index on Censorship, 31.03.2020.
  • Mühlhoff, Rainer: Digitale Grundrechte nach Corona - Warum wir gerade jetzt eine Debatte über Datenschutz brauchen, Netzpolitik.org, 31.03.2020.
  • Carville, Olivia; Court, Emma; Brown, Kristen V.: Hospitals Tell Doctors They’ll Be Fired If They Speak Out About Lack of Gear, Bloomberg, 31.03.2020.
    Edward Snowden on Twitter, 31.03.2020: We need to know whether our hospitals are safe. If we can't even prevent retaliation against healthcare workers for warning of hazards during a pandemic, "whistleblower protection" is a cruel myth.
  • Bluetooth tracking and COVID-19: A tech primer, Privacy International, 31.03.2020.
  • Bolton, Alexander: McConnell: Impeachment distracted government from coronavirus threat, The Hill, 31.03.2020.
    Quote: Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) on Tuesday blamed the Democrats’ push to impeach President Trump in January for distracting the Trump administration from the threat posed by the coronavirus.
    Several tweets pointed out that the impeachment did not prevent Trump from going on campaign rallies and playing golf. For example, vlh / @coton_luver on 01.04.2020: (…) Donald Trump admits he was distracted by impeachment and that impacted his decision making. Fails to mention the 9 rallies and 6 rounds of golf he played.

    Interview with Jutta Treviranus. See also Designing a Future Where Everyone Counts.
